Obviously I am not a sour guy, no matter how hard I try. This is dry, funky and has a ton of blueberries, but doesn"t quite  tickle my palate the right way. Still its a great beer, but I preferred the mellower, more austere Mamouche to this. Couldnt taste the rareness on this one.
Bottle at RBJG 2 Grand Tasting, thanks sunevdj. 2009 vintage. Red colour with a small white head. Some lacing. Sour berry aroma. Very sour flavour with hints of berries. Sour berry aftertaste.

Rating 1000 at the RB Japan Gathering. Thanks to Sune! I had been wanting to drink this for a long time. Maybe got a bit over excited and didnt write much.
Aroma lovely, fruity, lovely. Pretty sour finish. Beautiful.
Basically the usual Cantillon classiness and sourness with a different fruit which I also happen to like. Got to be a winner. Plus you could taste the rareness...
Hazy purple color. Blueberries, leather, funk and barnhouse. Uber sour with blueberries. Like a sour blueberry milkshake.

2012 75cl Bottle at Torst.. shared with Mark. Pour is a light blue/purple with a nice white head. Aroma of tart blueberries. Taste is same. Drinks like a nice sparkling blueberry soda. Finished the bottle in 3-5 minutes. Really tasty.

750ml bottle, apparently from 2007 .. . been wanting this since i heard the first release was due .. . getting alot of strawberry and mild blueberry jam .. . light mouth . . this is definitely more tart than sour, glad to have finally tried it .. . . did we go over choke holds?

02-MAR-2013, 2010 vintage 0,375 l bottle, @home, from Ølbutikken.
Opened with Morten to celebrate a huge tax refund. I have been holding on to this bottle since release. How will it present itself?
Pours slightly hazy red with lasting, lacing pink head.
Aroma is blueberry, tart, gun powder - lactic, and funk.
Taste the same. Mostly just pure blueberry juice.
Quite full body, soft but still lively carbonation with a long tart and blueberry finish. 
My first perfect beer, my first perfect 5. Must seek out again:-)
The perfect 5 may be influenced by the hype around the brew and/or the tax refund, but this IS the best beer I have had.

2007 vintage (not sure if it was batch 2 or 3) shared thanks to mlunger12 at RBWG! Pours a hazy reddish purple from the bottle with thin ring of white lacy head. Aroma of funky farmhouse yeast and tart fruit; taste follows, bittery tart awesomeness. Wow, this was pretty awesome.

2007 vintage I believe shared at the RBWG courtesy of mlunger12. Poured from 75 cl bottle into a tulip. Violet color fading to watery blue transparency on the edges. Little/no carbonation with thin off-white head that quickly faded. Nose is acidic funk, vinegar, blueberry skins. Taste is similar with tart blueberry, lemon rind, and tannins. Very crisp and dry. Excellent.
Rbwg mlunger once again with a big one. Reddish purple white head collar. Funk and blueberry tart. Effervescent blueberry fruity and earth. I wish I had more.

Bottle share at Ma Che, Roma, 09/02/13. Big thanks to Luca (Mortlach) 2010 Vintage.
Hazed mahogony brown with a good beige/tan head.
Nose is horsey, sour/tarte, wood, apples, sour berry fruits.
Taste comprises sour and tarte berry fruits, woody tones, horse blanket, farmy, sour apples, yeast, funked up.
Medium bodied lending towards a dry finish.
Excellent stuff.
user_location: Hazlemere, the lower Xhitlerns, Buckinghamshire, ENGLAND

text: 09/02/2013 375ml bottle (thanks Fonefan!). Bordeaux con riflessi violacei, cupa, profonda, quasi impenetrabile, schiuma scura abbondante ma non molto persistente. Aroma di frutti di bosco e lieviti selvatici, sentori di stalla, leggero acetico. In bocca è molto acida, un po sgraziata, si sentono bene i mirtilli ma non si fondono in maniera armoniosa con il tutto, anche qui leggero acetico. Il corpo è un po esile. Buona certamente, ma delude un po le attese.

Rating #3500. Vintage 2012. 375mL bottle, courtesy of fiulijn (thank you very much, Alex!), pours a pink-tinged dark cranberry colour with a small pink head. Aroma is full of blueberries, blackberries, and cranberries, a mild funky quality, and some pitted fruits. Flavour is remarkably complex, full of what seems like more than just blueberries - though blueberries are the first fruit that spring to mind, along with blackberries and cranberries. There is a medium funkiness, along with a delicate vinous quality, and obviously a tart quality that is not puckering, but quite dry. Finishes lightly funky, very dry, a bit vinous and fairly fruity. Highly complex and one of my favourite Cantillons, though no doubt overhyped.

750ml bottle, batch 8, thanks Henrik! Pours a deep raspberry red to purple with thin pink head. Aroma is vinegar, dairy and some mild funk. Taste is light blueberry at the front with more vinegar sourness as it goes through. There is another fruit note (raspberry?) going on here but Im not sure what. The sour level is pretty spot on and there is very little fake blueberry. A nice fruit lambic if you like blueberry.
user_location: Morro Bay via Orange County, California, USA

text:
2010 375ml- A-cloudy raspberry red on the fringe with deep crimson center.  One finger of thinning pink head and minor lacing. S-Pungent cranberry, blueberry and raspberry foundations.  Nose begins with good salty funk, vinegar and dry oak and must.  Ends with a slight sour sting and berries.  M-smooth and good carbonation.  Some creaminess yet dry.  T-incredibly mild and smooth given the aroma.  Still pleasantly tart on the front and sour on the back.  Cranberries, raspberries and red table wine tannins create the solid structure of the taste.  Blueberries are there but not overwhelming.  Notes of lemon, vinegar, sour cream, earthy rhubarb and mild funk ornament the base.

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Poured from a 750 mL bottle into a tulip.  2012 vintage.  From notes.

Blåbær has a blue violet hue and is moderately transparent around the edges.  There is not much carbonation and barely any head; there is just a small off-white cap.  

The main aroma is blueberries, although the smell is not that strong.  There are some tart and funky notes that give it a little more character.

The flavor reminds me more of tart blueberry skin than the whole fruit.  It has that kind of hollowed out flavor to it, like there should be a more robust fruit flavor.  Because of that, the flavor does not really change that much over the course of the sip and lacks much complexity.  The blueberry has just a touch of sweetness to go along with its moderate tartness.  There are some funky nots, and a bit of dry, oaky tannins to go along with the tartness.

The body is only somewhat sour and acidic.  The lack of sweetness or real punch, combined with the light carbonation, make it feel duller on the palate than it is, with a medium lambic body.  There is just a bit of dryness at the end of the sip.

Considering I was dying to try this for a long time, it did not meet my expectations.  There are other Cantillon lambics I prefer.

Bottle poured to my friends navel.  Perfect pour.  Cheese filled aroma.  I really cant describe more than that.  No blueberry present.  Blueberry is upfront but fades quickly.  Slight acidity towards the finish.  Suck a dick Minnesota.

Bottled sample, 2007 vintage (batch 1) via and shared with oakbluff. Pale purple in colour with medium carbonation. Aromas are of fynj, cherry and blueberry, wood, and lemon peel. Quite tart and sour in the mouth (although not agressively so) with flavors of bright berries, lemon, a hint of sour cream, and flowers. Light bodied and highly drinkable. A world class beer.

Been fortunate enough to try both the 2011 (b7) and 2009 (b4, I think) vintages recently.  Both shared a gorgeous appearance unique to the style yet were wildly different from each other in every other regard.

The 11 emitted an exceptionally pungent aroma of fresh, juicy blueberries that would make most muffin aficionados jealous.  Its on the *very* short list of aromas that would get a 10/10 from me.  Taste was rather mild and boring, though.  Almost watery with barely any funk or tartness.

The 09 was exactly its opposite: nose lacked depth and pungency while the taste showed matured fruits, funk, classic Cantillon acidity, and an overall level of refinement that simply isnt in the fresher bottle.

Blabaer is the perfect example of the "<girl 1>s face on <girl 2>s body" dilemma in beer.

...But honestly, Im pretty sure I prefer FouFoune. :)

Vintage: 2012 - 37.5cl bottle poured into Loon flute. Poured after letting this sit out for about 30 minutes, but the flavours were still muted together so let it warm to about 55°F before actually enjoying and reviewing. Deep burgundy in color with slight tint of purplish ruby. Single (off-white) fingernail head on medium pour. Smells of lambic funk with notes of must, aged cheese, soft citrus, and very hidden blueberry notes. Taste follows the nose (blueberry is quite muffled). Disappointing considering fruit lambics are usually most enjoyable relatively fresh. The base lambic quality here is very enjoyable and smooth though - must, funk, and rounded - just wish the blueberry was a bit more pronounced. This particular vintage did not live up to the "hype" for me, but I look forward to trying another vintage of this to see how it compares.

Bottle shared by ludvig.

Aloooot of blueberry taste. I drank it fresh. Not much funk. But a very fresh taste with a good sourness.

Bottle 750ml. [2009]
Pours dirty pink/red with medium pink head. Aroma is of blueberries, sourness, fruits, funk. Taste is of sourness, fruits (blueberries), acidity. Palate: Well carbonated, somewhat ligth body. Overall: Not super duper intense blueberries, but they are there. Very good. Bottom of bottle is dirtier, "thick", darker. Very good, glad it was no porter.

UPDATED: DEC 5, 2014 28-10-2012: Bottle (750 ml) 2009. Traded by urbancaver, thanks Cam! Pinkish/red with purple reflects (the last pour was deep purple) with a small persistent white/pinkish head and good lacing. There was still plenty of blueberries in the aroma with the usual Cantillon barnyard and wild notes and hints of wood. Unlike the other ratings Ive saw here, I found the blueberries to be more present (and fresher) in taste than in the aroma. Agressive Cantillon-style barnyard/leather taste with nice wood notes. Dry, acidic and astringent mouthfeel. Good carbonation. This is the best fruited lambic Ive tasted so far (closely followed by Saint-Lamvinus)! 9-4-9-4-18 = 4.4

21-04-2013: Bottle (375 ml) 2012 vintage. Shared by Jeffo, thanks. Hazy reddish purple with a small pinkish head and little lacing. Aroma is of blueberry skin with light citris/lemony notes. Quite smooth on acidity. Taste is also of blueberry skin with some barnyard notes and a light but sticky herbal finish. Medium body. Medium carbonation. Slightly dry finish.  If I remember correctly, the blueberries were much brighter in the 09 vintage we had last year. Its still very blueberry forward, but not explosive. Really a long lasting blueberry skin aroma and taste. Good balance. Very nice lambic, just not as mindblowing as I remembered. 4-8-8-4-17 = 4.1

37.5cl 2012. Poors dark red. Foam disapears very quickly, lambic that is... Smell is very nice blueberry. Taste is average blueberry, other berries?, citric. A bit sweet and average acid. Its not a bad beer but for me this beer is overrated. There are many other Cantillons out there who are much less rare, take Mamouche for example. Many of the scores are due to the rarity I guess.
0.75l bottle at Mikkeler Bar, Copenhagen.  Pink-brown colour with a brown blueish medium head. Sour, vinager taste with a hint of blueberries and lingonberries.

2012 750 mL.  Purple/red pour into my cantillion tasting glass.  Beautiful to look at.  Sour blueberry aroma, lemon, and a bit vegetal (Im thinking bell pepper).  Flavor is sour lemon, pith,  minerals, vegetal component is more prominent and some blueberry.  Lighter body, decent carbonation.  I prefer many of their other fruit lambics.

UPDATED: FEB 23, 2014 blåbärssoppa! when its fresh it really tastes of blueberries, murky funky notes blended with blueberries a delicious treat. differs a lot between batches. but good all the time.

2009 375ml shared with brystmar.  Nice POP on the cork, plenty of carbonation left.  Poured dark purple., smell was sour wood with faint blueberries.  One of the best looking beers i have seen and taste follows suit.  Taste of lemon, blueberries ,tart berries accentuated by blueberries skin/pulp.  Truly a great experience

Medium pinkish brown head. Murky opaque brown body. Funky earthy blueberry aroma with medicinal lingonberry notes. Intense lingonberry cow shed taste with salty earthy notes. Sweetish-sour. Mid-bodied. Sharp, salty, metallic mouthfeel. Dryish-acidic chalky barnyard and horse blanket aftertaste with salty metallic blueberry notes. Sharply burning finish. Tastes lovely at first, but after a while all the sour salty metal starts getting to you, and it gets increasingly hard to drink. (0.75l bottle, Mikkeller Bar, Copenhagen.)

2009-2012 vertical, all 375 ml bottles. The 2009 pours haziest, and the beer gets both clearer and deeper in color as it goes from 2009 to 2012. Small ruby-tinted head on each, with 2012 disappearing relatively quickly. Aroma of blueberry, yogurt, oak, and earth; 2009 is the most sour, 2010 is the cleanest and best, with some rose petal notes, 2011 is the most vegetal and weakest, and 2012 is the sweetest (with vanilla) and fruitiest. The flavor has blueberry, leather, yogurt, wine, vanilla, and lactic acid; 2009 and 2010 are the most tart, but 10 is so, so clean. 11 is the least tart, most watery, and least carbonated, and 2012 is the sweetest and fruitiest and probably in the most need of age. 2010 is the clear winner and 2011 is the clear loser. I have averaged out the ratings. Great beer overall.

UPDATED: JAN 10, 2013 2011 vintage, generously provided by Rich. Thanks a bunch for sharing this treat Rich! No head on the pour, but it is a beautiful deep purple red in color. It is slightly hazy in clarity, it looks stunning. For being a year old at this point, there is still quite a bit of blueberry in the nose, much more than I remember when I originally tried this last year. Plump blueberries and some yogurt character. Blueberry is a little more subdued in the flavor, but is still quite present. There is also lemon rind, oak, and a generous amount of funk. Light mouthfeel, good acidity, lower carbonation, and a moderate lingering finish. One of the better fruit lambics Cantillon makes, but in term of fruit lambics I think I still prefer Fou Foune, Saint Lamnivus, and Lou Pepe Kriek.

750ml bottle shared by Matt when I was in Chicago, poured a violet reddish color with aromas of sweet blueberries, and some light tart berries.  Flavors are feint blueberries with a sweet and tart berry mix.  Nice blend of tart and sweetness, wouldt mind trying this one again.

Bottle shared at Woodshop 7. Pours a lovely dark strawberry/raspberry color. Deep strawberry aroma with accents of blueberry and acai. Blueberry and acai come through a lot in the flavor with a soft acidity. A really nice sour.

UPDATED: AUG 16, 2012 August 5, 2012 bottle shared by Brett at his tasting event. Dark purple pour with pinkish head that looked awesome.  Oh yeah and this was poured in Cantillon flutes for the group which made it even more bad ass.  Sour berries in the aroma and taste.  The balance on this was simply amazing, best lambic / sour I have had to date.  HUGE thanks to Brett for sharing a beer I never thought I would get to try.

Bottle shared at Wood Shop 7 by Yespr, 2012. Beautiful deep purple with lace. Cloudy, deep, dark. Got a huge stinky-ass barnyard nose with dust and leather. Really stinky. The blueberries just come in a bit underneath to make it pleasant. A little shocking a first, its so stanky. Taste gives a little more blueberry, nice tartness, lemon, old leather, dust, books. Really dry and funky.

At a tasting thx Matthieu87 for sharing ! 
75cl bottle 2011 
head: violet, beuatifful but dissapears fast 
Colour: red wine / purple /blue /violet , again beautifful 
Smell: wow what a sweet nose this has ! im a bit shocked actually ... Cuberdons ( look it up ), red fruits, sweet 
Taste: start is a bit sour, with notes of creme de cassis, very creamy, quite sweet, very fruity, awesome ! but i do expected a little bit more of this ...
Litte bit more work on the flavour rather than working on the appearance and it should be fine ...

Bottled. Pours deep purple with a huge pink head. Fair lacings.  Nose of earth, wood and blueberries. Tart flavor with fruit and wood. Medium bodied, watery to oily texture  and soft carbonation. Ends up dry. An awesome fruit lambic.

Batch 6 750.
Pours a faint purple color. A 2 finger pink head that recedes to a thin ring. A very beautiful beer. 

smells of funk and earth. The blueberries are coming through in a big way. It smells very tart! 

tart blueberries that are followed up by more tart blueberries.  With that lovely cantillon funk. No one does it better.

2012 vintage. 375 ml bottle at Olbutikken, into small Cantillon glass.
Looks like one would expect, not quite opaque blueberry color, gushing head to start but fades quickly, tastes of lemon, blueberry, vinegar, hint of dill?  Approachably sour, tart berry flavor, I would like even more berry.  Carb and consistency are perfect.  Very nice lambic.

Bottle shared at Ølbutikken, Copenhagen.  Pours hazy red wine like  with a small pink head.  Aroma is tart, berries, earth and barnyard.  Flavour is light sour, not so in your face as other Cantillons, smooth and fruity with a soft carbonation.  Light and easy to drink.

2009 (batch 4) bottle shared at Muckfest III by Puddintane...thanks Dave! - Pours purple with a ring of white head. Light plasticy tartness--not shower curtain, thank God--fruity, earthy, funky. Can say I pick out blueberry, though theres a light fruity tartness to it. Taste is nice tart vinegar with a berry fruitiness to it. Nice tart acetic note, tangy and crisp. Real nice carbonation with a fluffy body. Been waiting forever to try this, and while it wasnt a religious experience, it was pretty damn good. Wouldnt chop off my arm to get one though--I couldnt imagine if Id paid a couple hundred dollars for this bottle.

Bottle, 2010 ed, courtesy GT2. Thanks bro! Pour is dark blue/purple with a dark pink head. Some retention/no lace. Aroma of dust, overripe blueberries, medicinal notes, lemon. Taste is tart, blueberry, lemon, dust, medicinal notes. Palate is dry, tart, sharp carbonation, short funky finish. Interesting.

2010 Vintage  Thanks to GT2 Pour is a beautiful blueberry pie color. with a frothy white head. Aroma is spicy with some soft blueberry to balance. Really light and fresh and has almost a floral quality. You get the fresh blueberry taste that plays off the lambic soureness. This is definitely something I want on a hot summers day.

UPDATED: AUG 11, 2013 Bottle from Gert . 75 cl. Vintage 12. Very small head. Good carbonation. Hazy Bordeaux red. Aromas of black fruit. Not especially blueberry. Maybe I expected more from this hyped brew. Dry tart medium body. Still a great great experience brew. 2013 version. Drink in at Ã¸lbutikken. Raspberry red. Aroma strong red fruit. Gentle not very sour. Lighter 2012.  3.6
Sampled at Small Peen tasting.  Purple color and foam.  I smell more funk and sour than blueberry.  Total funk is tasted.  Blueberries in the background.  Too sour and funky for me.

Pour out of 375 mL bottle, 2011 vintage.  Celebration for finishing first year of medical school.  Dark reddish purple pour with fluffy pink head, literally pink with nice fine bubbles, streaming off the bottom of the glass.  Aroma has wonderful notes of fresh wild blueberries, parmesan cheese, lactic acid, lemon, horseblanket notes come through with a hint of earthy tones, some big acidic berry notes with some boysenberry.  Wow.  Taste is tart wild blueberry, some earthy tones, and tart lemon fading to some nice horse and dusty basement, some nice lemon and lactic acid towards the end drying out with a hint more blueberry, finishing bone dry with a tart sour finish.  Delicious.

Thanks to Brad for sharing this at his tasting on Saturday!

Batch 4.

A: This brew pours a stunning shade of deep blue, bordering on purple, with radiant crimson hues that give the beer a brilliant appearance. Sitting atop the liquid is a thick layer of lilac colored bubbles. The head retention is something to behold. I have never seen a head camp out for this duration of time, most especially on any Cantillon offering. Im not sure if its ever going to fade.

S: Distinctive and easily recognizable as Cantillon. Tart fruits and barnyard funk aromas. Its difficult to single out blueberries, though the overall aroma is fantastic.

T: Sour blueberries as fresh as they can be, balanced with enough tartness to make the beer utterly slammable. Wow. This beer is just phenomenal.

M: The feel is a bit on the thin side. If it was perhaps a tad thicker, maybe it could be even more tart and fruity?

D: I truly wish this was more available. Definitely one of the best beers I have ever had.

Shared with friends 2009 Vintage 750ML format. Enjoyed in a Hill Farmstead glass. 

A - Dark plum and raspberry appearance. Minor line of carbonation.

S - Wow. Intense scent. Tons of blueberry. Big oakiness. Super tart nose back of the throat. Very very sweet. This smells wonderful.

T - Holy moly. This is an incredible beer. Gigantic up-front tartness with a barrel of blueberries. Nice. Just fantastic.

M - 20% carbonation on the mouth feel. Oily and slick and super tart. Very balanced dry finish.

O - 98/100. All aspects of this beer are great. Im in love. Very nice and very enjoyable.

Bottle.37,5cl...vintage ´12 sheared with Karin.....It pours hazy deep purple with a small pink head....very nice color..... The aroma is sour, blueberry, strawberry and some wood...... The flavor is tart blueberry, vinegar, grape and acid......medium body.... just delicious....

Assuming its a 2010 bottle as it doesnt have a year on it.  Pours deep red with a small pink head.  Nose is berries, not necessarily blueberry though.  The blueberry doesnt stand out.  Mostly funk here though, lots of vinegar and sour fruit.  Taste is sweet slightly and massively tart.  Mouthfeel is soft and smooth, with a decent crispness.  Light body with a long finish.

2011 bottle to celebrate my birthday. It pours cloudy deep purple, with a light pink head. The nose is sweet blueberry, jam, strawberry, honey, floral, farmyard and some wood. The taste is tart blueberry, lemon, vinegar, moderate acidity, floral, wood and farmyard with lingering tartness. Dry finish. Medium body and fine, prickly carbonation. Great balance of fruit and tartness. Delicious.

UPDATED: SEP 20, 2013 Thanks to Steffen for Sharing this. 
Pour deep murky ruby-red, with a small fluffy pink head. 
Aroma of fresh berries, slight vinegar, slight funky yeastyness, slight barnyard-stuff. Slight parfume(?) Lol. 
Taste is pretty sour, with just faint hints of fruity sweetness. Well balanced. 
Medium body, with some semi-flat carb.  (8-4-7-3-18: 4.0)

2013 vintage - drunk fresh.
Pour a beautiful clear dark ruby red, with a huge fluffy but quickly disappearing pink head. This fresh bottle has a lot more fruity notes to it than the older ones Ive had (no shit?) - Blueberry jam comes to mind. Wild berries, ripe and unripe blueberries, slight horse blanket/barnyard, over ripe pears and some notes of the white stuff between the meat of a lemon and the peel. Really tasty and very well balanced. 
The taste is still pretty darn sour, but has those blueberry-jammy sweet notes to it. Medium body with a fizzy carbonation. This beer really shines when drunk fresh imo. Tasty stuff indeed. (9-4-8-4-18: 4.3)
2011 Vintage tasted at Mikkeller Bar. Less blueberry than I imagined. Nice overall fruityness, and a good tartness that lasts a long time. A great beer but not the best.

bottled, rbesg07 grand tasting. pinkish red and quite flat; aroma of public toilet and sunny day garbage truck with a hint of wild berry seed; loads of tartness with the blueberry providing some refreshing and light sweetness suggesting vanilla custard. crazy stuff indeed

Bottle at Damicos. this was a whale of mine for years, very excited to try this one. pours a beautiful pink rosy color with little head. nose is blueberry, bosenberry, loganberry, cranberry and slight acetic acid. first sip is peerfect balance of sour and berry flavor. finish is clean wwith slight bittrness like the unripe blueberries. F*cking amazing!

Bottle 37,5 cl 2011 shared with Lotta. Pours clear deep blue lilac with a great shortlived pink blue head leaving lace. Aroma is stable horse blanket cellar dry leather and lots of delicious blueberries. Flavor is sour tart vinous and dry in front, more berry and cellar with leather tones in the middle yet keeping the tart blueberry flavor alive and all the way to the "bitter" finish. Finishes sour tart blueberries and a bit dry peppery.

75cl 2010 bottle @ Mikkeller Bar during CBC week. The pours deep reddish purple in color with a small strawberry red head. The nose is sweet blueberry and blackberries, some sweet fruity yeasty cheddar cheese and yeast. Fresh smelling. The taste is bright blackberry and blueberry juice. Cola sweet syrupy grapes and cranberry. Some yeasty funky notes. Yet, this is a bit more mellow and fruity than I was expecting, it definitely will be fine aging for longer. The bodys very silky and highly drinkable, light and jammy. Overall, a very good beer indeed. Glad I was able to try this!

There are many beers to tempt patrons on the Mikkeller Bars bottle list, but this one is right up there in the rarity stakes, so I decided to go for it. The barman wasnt sure if they had the smaller-sized bottle in stock but lo and behold he brought back an unlabelled 375ml bottle from the 2011 vintage. After halting a gush of foam the beer poured out a luscious red with a thin cap that stays for the duration. Already I could smell a mélange of blueberry, redcurrant and cherry, with a few oaky and medicinal notes too. As expected, its gorgeously lip-smacking and tart, but it doesnt go overboard. Its just perfect in this department. Oak barrel is there, smoothing out the sides. The pithy fruitiness really gets behind your teeth. No corner of your mouth is left unspared. 

Confession time: at first I found it hard not to be underwhelmed. Id heard the hype and perhaps it was no surprise that Blåbær didnt live up to it at first. But as the glass slowly emptied I found myself more and more taken in by this lambic. When there were only a few sips left I was near left near devastated! At that point I thought "I could go on drinking this forever." Theres probably no higher compliment.
A: blueberry, cherry, yeasts. A: deep purple. T: very sour and fruity. P: mb, watery. O: 18/20

UPDATED: AUG 28, 2015 Wee bottle 2011 edition, thx Svend. Shared at my wifes birthday 2012-05-13
Ar: tart dried red forest berries, fizzy, wee blueberries
Ap: ruby fizzy body, wee fizzy purple head
F: dry, tart lingonberry and bluberries, champange fizzy full flavored body, the yolk is the same as the rest of the bottle, its very good but I was expecting more blueberries, mmm there is some sort of marzipan there
 in the finish and as well Ekströms Blueberry soup...
And yes it was very good with the pistaco, pear, marzipan ice cream cake ;).

Shared by Dak.  Pours a cool blueberry color with a pinkish head.  Aroma is blueberry, funky and sour.  Taste is sour and fruity.  Medium bodied with an dry finish.  Really nice fruity lambic.  Awesome!

0.75l bottle the 2011 edition, shared with The Tasting Crew & friends. An epic one that we have been saving for a while. Its time to pop it! It pours a fantastic looking near clear amethyst-reddish body with a nice medium sized pinkish-red head that quickly sticks to the side of the glasses. It honestly smells like a juiced up blueberry juice blended with lemons, black currants, gooseberries, red currants and yeah, its just a damn fruity and really likable aroma. Lets taste! Yeah, it tastes just as good as it smells. Even more blueberries in the taste, it has a mild and round sourness thats just the perfect amount, its fruity with red currants, blackberries, lemons and actually it tastes just as good as I had thought/hoped. Ends mildly green grape-ish with a looong lasting aftertaste. Had this with blue cheese and it just lifted the whole thing to a new level. A big thanks to Mogens and ClubGonzo for supplying this magic beer for us! 13.04.2012

Bottle shared with (and great courtasy of) the fantastic Bergen tasting crew with such stars as ClubGonzo, Inbreak and Palme, and the mighty StoreMy. Vintage 2011. The color is nice and red like a good lemonade or something, and is a little bit unclear. A small pink head adorns the top. The aroma appears to be acidic and with some sweetness. Furthermore the beer smells of sour berries, black currant, and hints of blueberries in the end. In addition some typical horse. Quite tart flavor with tart berries, juniper berries, crowberries, blueberries and a touch of forest at the end. Mouth feel is both a little rich and soft, and with a light berry bitterness. This is without doubt a great Lambic, but had perhaps expected a further touch of blueberry.

My contribution to the whale tasting we had yesterday. 2011 vintage. Looks outstanding. Deep and reflective of the fruit its made with. Smells great; fruity and funky. Tastes delicious! Much like it smells. Mouthfeel is great too. Awesome stuff!

UPDATED: MAY 21, 2014 Bottle, shared with Bergen Beer Geek Tasting Crews Epic Abstrakt/Blåbær tasting, feat. special guests Foffern and StoreMy. :-) Whohooo! At last. After all this time. All this effort. All the money, sweat and frustrations. A big thanks to Mogens in Copenhagen for getting us this! :-) 2011 bottle. Expectations are sky-high, lets see if it delivers. Deep cherry-hued pink body with a medium, creamy dense pink retention. Aroma is mild and oh so balanced bretty tones with loads of berries, each one progressing as the aroma whiffs out: black currants, red currants, blackberries and finally - as it fades out: sweet blueberry. Hints of leather and barnyard funk. Taste is tart, dry grape and barnyard funky tones with sour blueberry notes. Blueberry is present throughout the palate, with hints of zesty lemon and horseblanket towards the end. Absolutely awesome, and worth its hype without a doubt. I really like the fact that the subtle berries actually make their way through the stable and sour tones. Im not sure if this is the best sour Ive ever tasted, but its definitely up there, at least in the fruit division. Sure glad to have tried this.

Bottle @ Mikkeller, 2009. Ruby with pink edges, gorgeous. Fruity and tart (such are the properties  of blueberries). Raspberries in addition, perhaps, over barnyard and wood. A fitting tribute to one of the best places in the world :)

Ausgeprägt saurer aber runder Antrunk, der später noch saurer wird. Dabei geht die Fruchtigkeit am Anfang etwas verloren, steigt aber später unmerklich wieder etwas an, was insgesamt eine ausgewogene Fruchtigkeit ergibt. Schöne SÄure auch zum Ende, unglaublich weich.

2009 bottle. Pours dark ruby with average, fizzy pink head; decent retention and minimal lacing. Aroma is raspberry, sour fruit, plastic, woody notes, and blueberries. Flavor is tart fruit and some earthy notes; rubber/plastic taste throughout; dry, tart finish. Medium body, carbonation, and warmth.

2009 bottle shared by ygtbsm94.  Pours hazy garnet with a medium, fizzy pink head, medium retention with light lacing.  Aroma is heavy phenols of bandage, plastic and smoke, blueberries, straw and hay malt with light spicy hops.  Flavor is tart blueberry, medium phenolic, malt backbone with a dry finish.  Medium body and carbonation, light warmth.

reviewed on 11-20-2011. huge thanks to Sean9689. batch 4 2009 375ml. pour was a dark dirty murky pinkish ruby. kind of like ruby red grapefruit juice. deep cherry and fresh blueberry with hints of sour lemon and dry oak. up front, there was almost a bright cherry aspect going on. through the back end and the finish this ripe fresh blueberry just lingered and stuck to the tongue for plenty of wonderful aftertaste. nice light oak and sourness through out to really carry this. lots of depth in this. light and zesty with mild to moderate carbonation. some dryness in the finish. dry blueberry in the mouth afterwards. overall, amazing. nuff said.

Bottle @ Home, 2011 vintage. Pours hazy dark red with a light pink head. Aroma of barnyard, dusty, blueberries, mould, sourness. Taste is dusty barnyard, horseblanket, sweet blueberries, mould, wood, light vinegar. Thin body, soft carbonation, sour dry finish. 170312

Bottle @ fonefan tasting. Vintage 2011. Hazy dark red with a lasting pink head. Aroma is sweet, malty, blueberries and moderate sour barnyard. Flavor is medium sweet and moderate acidic. Dry and moderate acidic finish. 270112

375 ml bottle. 2010 vintage. From Copenhagen, Denmark. Courtesy of mjs. Iso kiitos!
Dark red colour with small pink head. Sour and tart aroma with notes of manure and tart berries. Flavour is tart berries, more red berries than blueberries. Moderate sourness. Quite easy, maybe too easy to be excellent Lambic. Seems to be a bit overrated.

bottle  2011 vintage, thanks Søren. Pours deep ruby, deep red, with a small pink head. Aroma, some stable notes, dusty, light farty bacterial yeast. but the funny thing is that  this smells excactly like olives in brine, like those cheap pit less green and black olives you buy in a glass in the supermarket, weird! Taste: Very fruity, tart blueberries, skovbær,  brett, lacto notes, nice acidity, not overpowering, dry, strawberries, minerally notes, iron, red meat, lemon citrussy, very tart but not too acidic, Ive tasted other vintages of this 2009. and 2010, but didnt rate them. the 2011 vintage is not as good as they were.

Bottle @ Too many Geuzes - only one toilet , Ulfborg 2012 - Day 1.  2011 Vintage. Dark red, with a nice frothy reddish head. Aroma of sour blueberries, wood, horse blanket, quite tart. Taste balances betwwen sour and sweet berries, wood, vinegar. Quite nice.

2009 on the label. Christmas Present from Kristin drank on Valentines Day -wow, talk about a whale, cant believe I am drinking this. Pours thick like a smoothie, darker purple almost deep blood crimson towards the bottom, and the color fades consistently to lighter purple with a thick unclear body overall. There is barely a white head but appears bubbly. The aroma is berries, more blackberries/black raspberry notes with some tanginess and funky wild yeast that foreshadow a sour flavor. The body is thick and very lightly carbonated which makes it seem even thicker, again like a smoothie. The flavor is super, super sour, no wonder why the dude is puckering. The berry flavor is more tart than fresh bluebes, being that it is 3 years old. Super sour, super delicious, dry but not too dry of an ending, just puckering.

Wow, Big thanks to Shades of Gray for opening this up at our Darkness Day tasting. 

Am I really about to drink this?!?!?!

Wonderful blueberry notes and a grape blue color. Looks excellent. Taste is of sour funk and very sour blueberry. Not too much berry flavor in there but it does show a bit. The sour/tart is perfect and this is definitely a real treat. I think I was the only one freaking out about trying this. Everyone else was acting too cool and "no big deal" like. Simply awesome.

Cantillon Blabær Lambik pours cloudy purple and pink color.  Its a color Ive never seen in a beer before.  Beautiful.  Pink head laces the glass.  Right off the bat youll notice the fantastic aroma this beer gives off.  Oaky up front with a beautiful mixture of blueberry, leather, and funk.  The Vice Blogger thought it was one of the more sour noses and tastes he had ever had.  While I thought it was nice and sour and was actually pretty tame.  The taste is amazing.  The berries come out more here.  Everything is balanced perfectly.  Sourness, tartness, oak, funk.  Nothing got in the way of another ingredient.  The mouthfeel was one of the best qualities of this beer.  Smooth and velvety.  Medium bodied but more on the full side.

375 ml bottle courtesy of daknole.  Pours a bright reddish purple color with a medium plus pink head.  The enticing aroma pops with tart blueberries, wood, funk and some earthy herbal notes.  I am ready for the first taste.  The flavor has the sour/tart blueberries as expected.  Additional flavors of wood, funk, earthy notes and some vinegar that all work together extremely well.  There is a moderate acidity throughout, but not enough to get in the way of an incredible experience.  Very drinkable for what it is.  With beers like this I still feel that I lack the vocabulary to fully do it justice.

Bottle at home with guys from ØlKonsortiet. Pours dark purple-ish with a beautiful pink head. Aroma is funky and the blueberry really comes through. Nice fruity, dry taste/mohtufeel - no bitterness as expexted. Absolutelly wonderful!!!

UPDATED: JAN 12, 2013 2011 bottle. Very inviting, dark and rich in color.  Complex barnyard funk on the nose with controlled blueberry. Flinty and mineral as well. The fruityness is very ballanced and controlled. Zesty first impressions on the palate. Great ballance again but with all the tart profile one could wish for. The blueberry adds an extra dimension without being overpowering. Mineral, tart, citrussy aftertaste and just so sippable. 
The 2007 bottle is much lighter in colour, lots of fruit still and barn..  A lot more tart in flavour but still very very good. Tak til Svend aka enjoyit for this rare treat. I get why this is hard to find..

UPDATED: JUL 20, 2013 2011 vintage from my secret santa. Thank you so much!!! Absolutely beautiful appearance with a deep purple appearance with a rosey pink head. Rich blueberry, quite funky, tart fruity, tangy dark berry aroma. Incredible tart blueberry, big funky, tangy, mild citrus, light cranberry, light vinegar, sour flavor. The blueberry flavor is nothing short of phenomenal. I love it!

2009 bottle shared by Clever and DalzAle. Pours hazy ruby pink with little head and a wispy film. Aroma is tart funky farmhouse and spoiled fruit and leather. Taste is same as above with a strong sour flavor and I personnaly dont get any blueberries if anything I get lemon and apple peel. Palate is medium and very dry. Enjoyable!

2007 vintage 750ml.  Pours a hazy pinkish red with some sparse bubbles.  Smells of faint tarte blueberries, funky, some residual sweet touches, dank.  Tastes on the acidic end of the tarteness scale with some dry blueberry elements, and a puckering finish.
Cantillon never fail to impress, huge Blueberry aroma, with that famed sour funky smell as well. Tastes fantastic, as Cantillons always do, did I say I love Cantillon, haha.

Tasted on 8/24/11 from a capped and corked 750mL bottle, I believe this was the 2010 bottling.  Pours an opaque very dark blood red with a thick, even pink head that slowly recedes to a thin layer of pink lace.  The nose is full of burnt rubber barnyard funk, with a ton of fresh blueberry aroma and sour lemon acidity with just a bit of underlying vanilla oak treatment.  The flavor is tart and sour with a bunch of burnt rubber and earthy barnyard funk, but belongs to the fresh tart blueberries along with lemon acidity and a bit of oaky flavor as well.  The body is light with lively, almost sparkling carbonation and a super long tart blueberry, barnyard funk, and tannic oak finish.

Tart dusty musty blueberry nose. Lemon, light funky. Pours purplish red, nice fizzy white head. Flavors of lemons, blueberries, basement mustiness, and tart sourness. Lively carbonation, flavorful and refreshing. Spot on well done stuff! Hell yeah!

75 cl. Thanks rene! Corked and capped and gold foiled. Bright burgundy with a loose gray rim. Big tart basement and berry nose. Creamy medium body with bright carb. Lemon and basement mid palate. Berry bright flavor profile. Tons of sharp forward flavor. Delicious.
Batch 7. Pours dark red with a rosa head. Aroma is blueberries, sulfur, barnyard, acidic and leather. Flavour is dry, acidic, blieberries, leather, sulfur and barnyard. Very dry aftertaste.

Bottle: Batch 6:
Nice pink head pretty vast but sparkling and disappears quick.
Leaves a deep dark murky purple colored beer.
The color of this beer is beautiful!
Smell fresh wood, perfume, light soap, light earth, berries, light sulphur.
(Smelling this made me go back and wander through Cantillon brewery again)
Taste is a soft and not so sour (for Cantillon) mix of red and purple fruit, berries, wood, light vinous, yoghurt sourness, light to medium dry.
Well balanced and very tasty!
Nice berries (and red fruit) wood dry aftertaste.
Low to no carbo, soft light tingly (very light sparkling) light dry ish mouthfeel, full body and a texture between watery and very light creamy.
Nice brew and way softer than any other Cantillon Lambic I have had.
Worth its hype!

text: Intense deep purple to brown body. Very sulphuric aroma, fruity, intense wine-like flavours. Taste shows obvious signs of wood, very soft, some caramel sweetness. Not all that sour compared to other Cantillons.
Pours a hazy and burgundy red beer with a reddish head. The aroma is fruit, sulfur and tart. The flavor is fruit and acidity. The palate is dry and acidic. Overall a really good beer.

batch 7
nose is heavy sour fruit, underplayed barn yard, almond, weak rhubarb, feel is mediumbroad, carb is medium, taste is decent mellow and broad blueberry and raspberry after a sour start with a medium hay note. later weak sweet leaves.

37,5cl bottle. Vintage 2009 (batch 4). Pours a cloudy deep ruby/purple colour with a nice pinkish head. The head dissipates fairly quickly. Woderfully complex aroma: lots of berries and red fruits in general, hay, flowers. Lightly sweet, moderately acidic flavor, becomes moderately sour. Taste is really complex and fruity, but not sweet at all. Really sour, but still balanced thanks to the good amount of fruit presence. In the middle of the mouth, the fruity presence is typical berry tartness, with no specific reminescence of blueberris in particular if not told so. The aftertaste, though, is pure blueberries. Acidic, pretty dry finish. Medium body, lively carbonation. I cant say this is the best fruit lambic had so far, but its definitely up there, together with Lou Pepe Kriek to me.

Bottles courtesy of fata and daknole -- thanks, guys!  This is a very fine beer.  Pours a light golden color with a violet tint that shows in the head.  Loaded with vinegar and candied sugar in the nose with a hint of tart blueberries.  The flavor is dominated more by the tartness of the blueberrys skin rather than the sweetness of the inner fruit, but thats more a distinction than a knock.  Very memorable for binding the berry with Cantillons yeast.

UPDATED: AUG 7, 2012 Bottle @ Mikkeller Bar on October 15. 2011 vintage. Pours hazy reddish blue with a thick pinkish blue head that slowly dissipates. Looks like blåbärssoppa. Smell is sour with hay, leather, green apples, funk and subtle hints of bilberries. Taste is incredibly pleasant with lots and lots of sour bilberries, lemon, leather, funk and hay. Taste is incredibly complex with lots going on. As the beer gets warmer it gets sweeter and the bilberries become even more prominent. Mouthfeel is soft with small bilberry seeds floating around in the liquid. Its not as intensely sour as other Cantillons. finish is packed with tart bilberries and lasts for ages. Incredible beer!

UPDATED: AUG 11, 2014 2011 Bottle. Pours a very deep red purple with a sexy solid pinky purple head. Aroma is tart with notes of blueberries, vinegar, stable, wood sweeter sugary fruity notes allmost like "tutti frutti" along with some winey notes. Taste is tart with notes of blueberries, rural stable notes, funkyness, some oak, wine, other sour berries and a light floral touch. unfair high drinkability due to the availability. 

2014 bottle. 

This years batch was the bomb! More fruity and less tart than the 2011. Really complex and vinous overall and also very gentle and with a nice balance between the fruitiness and the wilder sour notes. Bumbin this a notch up from 4,2 to 4,3 !

UPDATED: NOV 8, 2012 750 ml 2007 vintage bottle thanks to daknole. Opened before the last Jackie Os trip.  Tart blueberries with a complete balance of funk.  One of the best ive had to date. thanks man!

This was great.  Courtesy of a European Santa I believe.  Nose is what youve heard - tart blueberry, vinegar, tannin, candi sugar.  Color is a very fetching reddish purple with beautiful lacy violet head.  Flavor is like the nose - like a thin, tart jam.  Not the peppery, mouldy depth of a 3F Vintage, but formidable yeasty age plus very good fruit.

2011 bottle shared at Zwanze day. Pours a purpley red with minimal bubbles of a reddish hue. Nose is straight up Cantillon funk, yogurt, sharp berry notes and a rustic barnyard note. On tasting, intensely sour and dry. Light bitterness and saify blueberry notes are in the background. The defining component in this is the dryness. The blueberry really is a subtle note, letting the lemony cantillon character dominate. Solid.

Blåbær:
Doft: Det första som slår mig är hur mild och subtil blåbärsdoften är, den är inte lika in your face som körsbären från dess kriek eller hallonen från deras framboise. Ytterligare känner man, utöver den traditionella Cantillon-funken med sin halm och ladugård, en jordighet från blåbæren som framhäver en del alkohol, något som gjorde mig en aning förvånad. Det är inte ofta man känner alkohol i en Cantillon tycker jag.

Smak och munkänsla: Direkt känner man givetvis blåbären, mycket tydligare än i doften. Cantillonfunken jag nämnde ovan visar sig också tydligare. Därefter kommer en massa skogsbär tillsammans med lite pinje och jord i bakgrunden. Mild syra, vilket är att vänta med tanke på dess ringa ålder, med en nypa sötma som balanserar upp det hela riktigt fint. Ölen är torr och lätt och är varken komplicerad eller svårdrucken.

Utseende: 
Mörkröd/violett med en vackert rosa skum. Har inte druckit någon öl förut med den här färgen och måste säga att den är riktigt förtjusande.

Totalt: Blåbären gifter sig underbart med syran från ölen och den subtila sötman tillsammans med skogsbären gör att ölen blir en fröjd att dricka. Jag drack min första flaska Blåbær vid releasen i år och blev lätt besviken på smaken, men såhär i efterhand måste jag säga att min åsikt har skiftat. Blåbær förtjänar kanske inte all sin hype, men jag kommer garanterat köpa den nästa år trots dess höga pris, det, i alla fall, förtjänar den.

Another big thanks to Keith as he pulls out this 2009 vintage. Wow! Pours murky plum water with white head. The aroma has flower pedals, soured berry fruit, tart yeast, mild funkiness and a bit of growing body odor at the end of the draw. The taste is tart and moving into tartness and acidity with berry like notes around the edges. It gets funky and some what body odor like before the vinegar kicks in.

For me this one was mostly hype. I really liked the look of this one, the blue/purple apparance is unique. But for a lambic fruit there was really not much life to it. the taste was very thin, basically no sourness, if any. Definitely a disappointment but it was still a good beer to drink. My recommendation is to let this one age for a little while, I had the fresh batch. It needs time to let the sourness come through. I can see the makings of a really good beer but I believe it was too fresh. Glad I tried. Would like to get this one another go

2010 bottle share by Darkguardian at Coffee District. This was the first time having this beer and Im glad it was a fresh, because Ive had some aged Cantillons, which were awesome, but the fruit taste was pretty much gone. It was hard to drink this beer. First off, the blueberry and sourness in the nose was so great that I just kept smelling the beer. I was fearful that I would drink it in one shot because the smell was that good. The taste was even better. Blueberries were present but not overpowering. The tartness added some great puckering and made each sip better and better. I never pass on Cantillon and its because of beers like this one.

Batch 09 II by 375cl. Fantasy football is so much tastier while slowly sipping a tasty fruity lambic. Sour, funky aroma. Pungent waft up from the glass. Flavor is sour funk at first, you have to think long and hard to get past that to the fruit which is a pleasant albeit faint aspect working. The finish is gritty, earthy, a little like the outside of a blueberry and its skin. Incredible amount of funk and a little sourness tickling the back of your throat. One of the tastier drinks I have had in some time.

Bottle courtesy of meilby. 2010 vintage. Pours cloudy dark red hued purple with pink head. Aroma is basement, earth, vinegar and loads of blueberries. Taste is light sweet and medium sour. Medium body, thin, soft carbonation, a bit dry on the palate.  20110421

UPDATED: DEC 26, 2011 375ml 2011 bottle around 50 degrees F. pours a dark purple with a pretty explosive head that hold up for some time... can only see through the liquid up to the light. though it is very clear. im really intrigued by the look of this liquid as it swirls in a tulip. smell is potent and more vinous than berry. though it does smell like berry pie filling. funky notes but clean. the berry finds strength in the finish. taste is crisp lambic (see classic gueuze review) with a vinous berry taste. flavor pops to berry in the finish. moderate lactic sourness that gets rid of any sweetness. berry flavor is like a berry preserve/ jam. mouthfeel is crisp, dry with some tannic skins. moderate carbonation with light/medium body.
38cl, Vintage 2011, exclusive brew, with blueberries, thx to Jeppe!, complex sour fruit brew, slightly woody, easy to drink, very balanced, hazy, good head, very good brew, yet very expensive!

Huge thank you to Dobby for this one.  2011, Batch 7, 750 ml.  Pours a deep maroon and cloudy with a thin layer of bubbles.  Aroma is very good.  Lots of blueberries, earth, barnyard and mild cheese notes.  The berries dont seem terribly juicy, but its wonderfully restrained and complex.  The taste is dry with a tannic, blueberry skin quality.  Im guessing that my review would be very high for an older bottle because this one just doesnt seem to have the tartness of other Cantillon and 3F fruit lambics, and more sour berry flavor would put this over the top.  Still, its pretty great, as is.  Mouthfeel is fairly normal for the style - light, not too bubbly.  Good stuff.

vintage 6. juicy tannic blueberry nose and classic cantillon greatness. deep purple, becomes darker and more rich once i added the dregs. sharply tart, the berries offer some sweet balance. vintage 6. juicy tannic blueberry nose and classic cantillon greatness. deep purple, becomes darker and more rich once i added the dregs. sharply tart, the berries offer some sweet balance.

A purple reddish beer with quickly dissapearing head. Aroma is leather/brett, blueberries, sourish, not so complex as expected, but delicious. Flavor is sourish with leather / smoke (brett), tart but still a touch of sweet, blueberries, bitterness and the finish is pretty bitter with a touch of alcohol. Palate is a bit thin, but soft, and prickles on the tongue. Less complex than I expected and not as refreshing neither, but it is indeed an interesting brew and certainly worth to try.

Bottle from 2009. Ken just pulled this out of his magic duffel bag. What a man. Pours cloudy, bloody red with a filmy head. Huge tart berry nose, very funky. Super sour flavor, light berry sweetness, some fresh grass, acid. Light bodied with soft carbonation. Dries out in the finish, more berries, tart and acidic, further funk, light apples, grass. Excellent stuff.

2011 vintage. Reddish purple with a pinkish head. Funky but not very sour. The blueberries arent very evident, though there is a general fruitiness. A good fruit lambic for sure, but far from the best IMO.

Vintage, piccolo assaggio, purtroppo era un brodo di lieviti e aveva preso daceto. Non il solito acetico di Cantillon, qualcosa di lievemente peggiore.

UPDATED: JUL 11, 2011 Batch 7 - 2011. Bottle shared with Clyx on a summer meadow outside Helsingborg. What a great atmosphere for a beer like this! Gunpowder smoke arise when releasing the cork and foam starts to build in the bottle. The beer is almost escaping on us. When poured into a glass the liquid appears deep red-purple coloured with a pink soft precautious head. Gentle aromas of blueberry soup, crushed blueberries with a light acidity to it. Softer then many other cantillons. A light sweetness, some black currant and fresh cranberries is also apparent in the nose. As the beer sits for a while more earthy lambic notes surface.
The taste is dominated by sour blueberries - What a surprise, huh?! A nice acidity, bitterness and sweetness mixes up and ties together in a wonderful way. This is what makes the beer so stunning. The body is light but the taste and flavour incredibility rich and intense, the soft carbonation does the trick and works well with the beer. Taste continues with notes of green apples, lime peel and more creamy blueberries. It coats my mouth and just doesnt go away, aftertaste is just as good as the rest of the beer. This beer is a big subject of hype but its my honest opinion that it deserves most of it. The uniqueness and character of the beer makes it worth trying. Id love to drink it again.

UPDATED: FEB 2, 2012 2010 Bottle from FOneFan. Dark ruby with small pink head. Aroma is blueberries, tart and barnyard. Flavour is blueberries, little tart, wood, barnyard, citrus, little sour, funky and horse blanket.
Bottle vintage 2010 traded from fonefan. Nice pink head with good duration. Color is dark ruby. Aroma and taste are rich blueberries, stable, leather and moderately acetic.

Bottle of 2011 vintage (batch 7). Pours a nice dark red/ruby color with a purple/pinkish head. Aroma is really nice and sour, with the blueberries, funk, vinous notes, cork, green apple, white grapes and barnyard notes. The flavor is fairly sour, but the sourness is nicely balanced by the blueberries, other than the blueberries, I get white blasamico, vinegar, a musty and old basement kind of flavor, barnyard, hay, white grapes, green apples, cork and in general alot of funk! The body is medium with a dry mouthfeel. Overal a really nice and very complex Fruit Lambic, probably the best Fruit Lambic I have had, it is definietly worth going to Copenhagen to get this awsome brew!

2011 Batch 7.

Aroma: Blueberry soup, marsipan, fruit toffe, seed charcter, earthy, kriek.

Funky, "sour" aroma with notes of lemons, blueberries, oak and barnyard/horse blanket. Reminds me (a bit) of blåbärssoppa. Taste is very dry and highly sour and tart, but in a way very balanced. More blueberries. Light bodied with light carbonation and dry mouthfeel. Long finish. Really good one, maybe a bit to sour for my taste. I really like the addition of blueberries.

Re-rating 2011-08-01:
375 ml bottle. 2011 vintage. Pretty much same appearance as earlier. Aroma is about as funky but with more blueberry notes and fruitier. Taste is more balanced as in less sour and also has more blueberry than the older one. Similar in other ways as well, but more blueberries and less sourness.

2010 75cl bottle. Well what can I say that everyone hasnt already said. The beer pours deep purple with plenty of carbonation; there is enough funk and horse blanket to set up your own imaginary farm. The taste has a perfect sourness level with plenty of Bret and fresh Blueberries and a soft mouth feel. Only problem with this beer is that it goes down far to easy, you try and savour it but before you know its all gone and you are left wanting more. My favourite beer to date, massive thanks to traPISSED and Anker for getting me this one.

Small pour of the 2007 black foil vintage generously shared by Shaun Hill himself on the night before HF anniversary. Hazy pinkish pour with a few bubbles of foam. Aroma is a pure wonder. Lots of blueberry remains on the aroma despite this bottles age, with the regular lambic aromas coming out as a nice dry spiciness, almost peppery. Taste is super fruity but quite acidic too. Never has there been such a perfect match between a fruits acidic/sweet character and lambics funk/acidity. Everything just blends perfectly into one of my new favourite beers all time. Stunning.

09 bottle from GT - many thanks my friend.  Pours a thick dark red color with a massive tower of light raspberry colored foam.  Highly carbonated.  Aroma is a light berry tart with some lemon and some tight funk through the finish.  Taste is initially sharp and tart berry that comes across to me more as a tart raspberry than blueberry.  The middle of the taste is dominated by medium tart/sour, lemon gueuze, and recurring sharp berry notes.  The finish is very dry with the lemon gueuze and tart reverberations from the berry.  Very well done fruit lambic.
Awesome sour brew..blueberry notes coming through along with the acidic finish. A must for sour heads.

UPDATED: DEC 31, 2015 Bottle 750ml vintage 2011 @ Geokkjer
Pours hazy amber/purple with a light pink to purple head. Aroma has notes of blueberries, funk, tart, barnyard and fruits. Taste is light to medium sweet and medium to heavy sour with a long dry, tart, blueberry, funky and fruity finish. Body is medium, texture is oily, carbonation is soft

Bottle 375ml vintage 2010 @ Zoney
Pours cloudy purple with a light purple head. Aroma is typical cantillon with hints of blueberries. Taste is heavy sour with a dry finish. Body is medium to full, texture is thin, carbonation is soft to fizzy. [8 4 8 4 17 - 4.1 4/28/2011]

Thank you Casey for this delicious treat. 2009 bottle. Well, there is no way that this beer could live up to the hype, so Im not setting up any expectations. Pours a dark, murky, red-purple with a thin, medium-fine rosy head. Huge barnyard aroma--damp hay, horseblanket, blue fruits--not blueberries expressly, thankfully. The flavor is quite sharp and sour, deliciously so, with a lot of the dark earthiness characteristic of Cantillon. The fruit characteristics come across quite strongly, unlike many other Cantillon fruit lambics in which the fruit is almost entirely fermented out.  Light, well-balanced body that conveys the dense flavor profile quite nimbly. Loved being able to try this, but probably wont be jumping through too many hoops to procure another bottle anytime soon.

Bottle from 09. Pours a purplish color with a pink color head to it. Has a funky blueberry smell to it. Has a lot of blueberry in the flavor along with the classic Cantillon funk and a bit tart. Not as sour as I thought it would be. A very nice beer Im glad to have had. Thanks Tom!!!

Shared 75 cl bottle courtesy of tarjei. Vintage 2007 (black foil). White film on a clear red-orange body. Fresh spicy apple cider vinegar in the aroma. Heavy acidity with berries. Astringent as the acidity lasts through to the finish. Light body. Eventually it becomes more dry than astringent.

Batch 004, thanks Brad. Poured into a tulip glass. Beer is ruby red, hazy, completely beautiful. Forms a pink head (pretty big) of medium bubbles.

Beer is superbly pungent. Tons of sour coming through, acetic and lactic with some funky woodsiness that pulls the whole thing together. I could smell this all day long.

Beer is thin and light in body. Carbonation in the mouth props the body up a bit. Very sour and tart, good fruit character. I could session this all day long. Know where I can get a keg of this stuff? If I had to criticize it I would say it finishes too quickly due to the low body. I know lambics are suppose to attenuate out at a gravity near that of water, this one seemed thinner than others. If it had a little more to it, slightly more body, I feel the fruit would have popped more. Enough complaining though. This was the best lambic Ive ever had and would drink it again, buy it again, trade for it again, fly to Europe to buy a bottle.

Serving type: bottle

From 11/05/10 notes. Had at a small tasting thanks to ygtbsm94; huge thanks to Brad for sharing this very sought after beer! Bottle is from Batch 3, 2007 Vintage.

a - Pours a reddish amber color with two inches of fluffy white head that has excellent rentention and leaves a little bit of lacing and light carbonation evident.

s - Smells of tart blueberry, sour fruits, brett, and oak. The blueberries arent overpowering, which makes it wonderful to smell and enjoy.

t - Tastes of blueberry, sour fruit, yeast, and brett. Hints of oak as well, but not as much as the smell. The tart blueberries come through a little more in the taste than the smell, but again, pretty amazing.

m - Medium body and low carbonation, very smooth and crazy drinkable. A little bit tart but not too lip puckering, which allows it be be drank easily. Perfect mouthfeel.

d - Wow, what an amazing beer. At 5% ABV, I feel like I could drink a whole bottle of this and still want more. Im not just marking this up due to rarity; this is one of the best beers Ive ever had and if you like blueberries as I do, youll love this one. We tried various sours at the tasting, including LeBleu and Crianza Helena and I enjoyed this one more than both of them; I came home the next day and immediately tried to trade for a bottle. Would love to have again sometime and truely worth the hype.

2010 750 / Batch 6 - shared with buds. Thanks to Ken for this one. Hazy pour with minimal head. Amazing aroma of barnyard funk and blueberries. Crazy nose of hay and sourness makes you want to breath this down more than drink it. Creamy taste with funky sourness and a complex mixture of blueberries, funk, apricots and lemon zest. Beautifully balanced. Finish is dry and lactic. Glad to try, worth the hype.

UPDATED: NOV 24, 2011 Ive had this several times now, 4 of the 6 batches. Batch 5 is by far the best if youre looking for blueberries. 

The beer pours a deep grape jelly colored purple with a nice medium pink head. The head rises about 3 fingers and is very creamy and soft with great retention and lace. Probably the best head Ive seen in a lambic. 

The aroma is medium with mostly tartness coming through, some horse blanket mostly. Its nice because you get the funkiness youre looking for but not so overpowering that you get tired of it. At the end you get a little sweetness, but not much blueberry. 

The taste is great, its super complex and well balanced. It starts soft and sweet and highly drinkable, towards the middle and end it evolves to have nice tartness. Once again, like the aroma it gets you the tartness you desire in drinking a lambic but not so overpowering that you cant drink a ton. At the end you finally get some blueberry mixed with a final tart goodbye.

2007 (Batch 3, I believe) bottle Max graciously opened at his FF winnings tasting to honor the return/birthday of Joe McPhee. Pours a hazy blood orange. Aroma is just phenomenal: a raspberry and floral bouquet with notes of lemon and barnyard. Theres also a sting of acetone that is just enough to draw your attention without being off-putting. Flavor is immediately acidic but quickly followed by lavender, soap, cherry, and old cheesy funk. Lots of dry funk despite the sharp acidic quality that lingers. In fact, the dryness somehow outlasts the acid. I have a massive crush on this beer.
Bottle at Maxs tasting. Amber with an off white head. Funky aroma, with fruity tart blueberry sweetness. Awesome fruity funky blueberry flavor. Awesome.

(Bottle, 0.375 l - 2010 Vintage, from Ølbutikken) The beer poured blueberry juice coloured (almost red) and cloudy. Its head was almost pink and medium sized. Aroma had sourness, fruitiness and blueberries. Palate was medium bodied and quite fizzy with medium carbonation. Flavours were sourness, blueberries, fruitiness, tartness, mildly grapefruit and very low bitterness. Aftertaste was fruity, tart and sour. I didnt know what to expect when I opened this bottle. The high ratings I knew but that was all. The beer lacked tartness and sourness which I like in lambics and that made the taste a bit disappointing. Otherwise a nice brew.

2009 Vintage, not honestly sure of the batch. Huge thanks to Smokepot for the share, however. Very generous of him! Pours murky raspberry/purple, thin pale pink head, spotty lacing. Nose is blueberries, Saskatoon berries, big tartness. Lambic shows through the fruit more as it warms up. Flavours of tart acid, big funk and berries. Really struck by the balance on this one. Very cool stuff.

Deep violet murky beer with a small pale purple head that pretty much, surprisingly sticks around for a minute.
On first whiff, smells like the rest of Cantillons offerings. But coming back to it every now and then reveals a complex layering of other aromas. Little sweetness that is absent from others, little fruitiness (different fruitiness) than some more. Overall a pleasant fruit filled barn.
Sour up front, and sour in the back. Just like their other brews. The blueberry lends a very complex characteristic to this that is hard to put my finger, erm tongue, on. I like it though.
Same as the rest of the Cantillon brood. Little thinnish, the sourness sticks around between each sip. But not unpleasant whatsoever.
Very drinkable. I could quaff these all night if it werent for the sour barrage unleashed on my tongue. I like sour, but you can only drink so many in an evening before you tongue gets pickled.

Bottle shared by alexsdad06 - Thank You!. Poured hazy purple color with a large frothy grape colored head that lasted with excellent lacing. Moderate to heavy tart fruit, yeast and alcohol aroma. Medium to full body with tingly smooth texture and soft carbonation. Moderate to heavy sour & sweet fruit flavor with a mdium to heavy tart fruit & sweet and small alcohol finish of moderate to long duration. This is a standout beer & lambic.

Bottle shared by badnewsbeers. Murky opaque, sediment-laden red-purple body, dense pink clumping head. Dry, cobwebby, floral fruity nose with blueberry and oak. Sour, quite tannic and oaky body with blueberry skin; soapy and cobwebby with a dry finish. Clean, refined, and very good.

375 ml bottle from Wavers. Thanks, Baker! Rating #2000, 2009 - Batch 4. Pours a wicked blueberry hue, purple red murky pour, rusty, dark with lighter notes, a huge cakey pink head sits atop, laces well and stays pretty big. Wine hued and murky, frankly quite gorgeous with a fluffy pink head that laces well. Aromas are amazingly sour, blueberries and funky bretty horseblanket, lemons, wet oak, bready malts come in behind with a spritzy nature, lactic acid. Horseblanket and bretty funk really start to assert itself, sour blueberries and lemons, dusty funk. Wet oak comes in stronger now as it warms a bit more. Initial is luscious blueberries, sourness dialed back a bit, lemons and wet oaky tannins make way into a bigger bretty funk, leather and horseblanket, hay and dust. Blueberries and berry back into the fold, juicy berries and sour juice, melons. Blueberry tannins, generic berry (raspberry in addition to blueberries), funk, dust, and oak. Really well crafted, not a sour bomb, bringing the funk power, but not losing its sour and juicy blueberry roots. It just keeps getting better further into it, warming a touch. Touches of yogurt and sour blueberries, blueberry tannins and oak lingering in the finish, funky brett sticks around on the palate, dry. Yogurt grows stronger. Good sour, funk, and flavors. Great drinkability, balance for a beer of its type. The acidity stays at bay a bit, but remains a nice sour kicker. A winner.

UPDATED: MAY 15, 2011 2009 375ml bottle shared with Weisguy for a mini lambic tasting.
Served a bit too cold, but hey, its January in Michigan. Poured a blueberry pulp red with lots of purple and a nice frothy white head. Immediate smell is vinegar even after just uncapping! The nose definitely foreshadowed the taste as it packs a powerful acidic kick in the mouth. Bit of sparkling fruit soda mid-taste & on the palate, but very enjoyable. Tastes very similar to Cantillon Kriek and its hard to get much blueberry out of the beer until sampling the last 4 ounces of dregs/sediment. The surprising acidity of the beer (for a 2009) burns lightly on the finish. Extremely drinkable. 8/4/8/5/17

Re-rate for 2009 (batch 4) 750ml:
Shared by Dan at Dereks first visit back tasting in April. Pours a vibrant purple with a pinkish head. Smell is a bit of funk, sweet blueberries, and vanilla. Taste is sour, funky, but accompanied by acidic blueberry skin with a dry finish. Woah, this was a very different beer compared to the batch 5 375ml I opened up some short time before. Way more blueberry fruit on the nose and taste which made all the difference in balancing the beer out. 9/4/9/5/20

bottle(thanks to Blomster) at my leaving FL throwdown1700(17Dec10)pours dark purple with a thin pink head.  Aroma is huge with barnyard sour wild yeast and dark fruit notes.  Flavor is very puckering tart grape and berry.  The blueberries come in the finish and leave the mouth super dry like sucking on the skins of blueberry or grapes.  This was so interesting and i would pick up new things after each sip.
2009 bottle. Many thanks to Mikey for sharing. Pours purple with pinkish head. Nose and taste of light wood, fresh blueberries, tart fruit and mildly acidic sourness.

HUGE thanks to Kevin for sharing this much sought after brew! 2009 bottle

A- Body is a dark opaque fuschia hue-havent seen another beer ever this color. Pours with a 1 finger soapy light pink head which fades to 1/2 finger and has perfect retention from there. Some lacing left behind in the glass.

S- Light notes of vinegar, wild sour blueberry, a light funk, a hint of raspberry and other berries as well. Excellent and balanced.

T- Wow. Very balanced. Sour blueberry, a hint of vinegar, a hint of sour tartness. Finish is slightly sweet and fruity but with a hint of lip-puckering tartness and vinegar. Left to linger are under-ripe berries, a hint of vinegar, and a slight tartness.

M- Carbonation is very light and slightly tingly. Body is light to medium weight, somewhat dry and slightly thin.

D- This is a phenomenal brew. Its very complex and balanced. Almost perfect-but not quite. Overall a great sour blueberry lambic and a brew that deserves to be much sought after.

Serving type: bottle

purple body. massive gusher from a 750ml bottle. pink head. just gorgeous. huge oak tannins, sourness, blueberry, must, and small sugar in the nose. flavor has more berry skin, tannins. tart yet sweet..big blueberry..spongy mouthfeel. good stuff, but certainly a hype-monster

Batch 6 (2010), consumed on 10.26.2010. Shared with BucketBoy. 

Pours a deeply purpled carmine. Theres a thin ring of lightly pink-hued head, but little lacing. 

Ripe, muddled blueberries and a minor funkiness that reminds me of blue cheese. As it opens, the soured blueberry character becomes more and more vibrant. 
Tart blueberries , some lactic acidity, and the tangy/sweet interplay of fresh black currants. The first sip was quite sour and masked some of the complexities lying underneath, which show their face as the beer warms. Sometimes the more complex something is, the more difficult it is to describe without appealing to more and more adjectives. Fewer is appropriate here: beautiful, wild berry flavor; ripe and almost-ripe blueberries; a soft mustiness.

Dry andtannic finish, leaving you wanting more. The drinkability is high, especially for the style.

Rating #2500!  12/17/10.  Bottle shared with huge thanks to Keith (fata2683) before he moved to AZ!  Nice purple and brown pour with a nice solid white head that is fluffy but goes fast.  Big funky aroma with soapy fruits, tannic fruit skins, and yeast.  Huge puckering sour flavor that lingers with huge blueberry skin... Im very impressed by the sourness without huge acid and vinegar.  Amazing!
Bottle courtesy of Keith, sour and bitter, little taste of blueberries, an absolute amazing lambic.

UPDATED: AUG 6, 2012 2009 Vintage.

A: Poured a deep ruby with a nice light ruby head that left a bit of lacing on its way down.

S: Quite a bit of lactic sourness, without much vinegar smells coming through like with Saint Lamnivus. Definitely quite a few blueberry notes marking their way in. A little bit of sweetness.

T: Quite a bit of acidity, but nothing too overwhelming like several other beers coming from Cantillon. The blueberry taste is simply astounding, blending beautifully with the sweet, tart sourness. The blueberry flavor is quite unique and pungent, tasting almost like crushed blueberries that had previously been frozen, as opposed to fresh blueberries.

M: Beautiful acidity balanced against a lovely fruit aroma--very well done. 

D: Very, very nice. Wish this had been a 750 as opposed to a 375. Exceptionally thrilled that I got to try this one out.

Serving type: bottle

Reviewed on: 03-08-2010

2007 Vintage, batch 2 - 750 ml bottle courtesy of a trade with yespr.  Pours a slightly hazed purple blush with a thin linen white head. Very pleasant aroma of blueberries, lemon, light vinegar, and some mild funk. The flavor is filled with tart blueberries and lemon, which is a lovely combination, with some mild vinegar present as well.  Clean, bright and effervescent on the palate.  Dries out at the finish.  Excellent!
