Bottle Batch 4: Pours a dark blueish hue with light tawny and mahogany hues and a nice puffy head. The nose is explosive with fruit; tart blueberries and other berries (huckle, cloud, black) come to mind along with that classic funky yeast dusty wooden barrel so typical of cantillon. The flavor is nice and mellow; sweet and tart berries along with a light kick of acidity from the yeast, very light compared to most Cantillon though. The finish is smooth and wineish with a complex tart tannic sweet mouthfeel and an ethereal tail. Thanks douglas88, awesome beer!

750 ml bottle thanks to the amazing Papsoe! Shared with Jordan and Eric at the Sushi Bar. Was a perfect night, cool and clear, great food and awesome beer. 2009 edition, batch 4. Pours a dark purple color with a medium pink almost purple head. A amazing nose; its all about that Cantillon yeast, funk, sourness, huge blueberries. The flavor was somewhat dry and not very sour; a full fruit lambic, easygoing, smooth, tart, rich blueberries, dry funk, very yeasty. Wonderful.

UPDATED: OCT 10, 2012 Bottle. Cork says bottled in 2010. Pours a really nice slightly hazes purple color with a pinkish head that both coasters and collars around the glass. Classic cantillon aroma with sour/tart notes but with the addition of subtle blueberries. Slight barnyard as well. Light mouhfeel with good carbonation. Starts sweet upfront with subtle blueberries and lemon zest. Not mouth puckering but for sure both sour and tart. Some barn type flavors as well. No real alcohol flavors. I can see why people chase this beer down as it is exceptionally good. I feel ba having to take this off my gots as this is my only one. Most recent 2012 version: Much less sour notes and more fruit forward. Good but IMO this beer is better with some age on it to bring a nice balance of sweet and sour.

375 bottle, batch 5, thanks to alfrantzell, a generous guy and great friend!

Well...what is there to say about this beer that hasnt already been said by one person or another?  The cork comes out with a slight pop, certainly not the great bang I was expecting, but nevertheless the beer is very properly carbonated.  The pour is a gorgeous violet hue.  The minute the bottle opened, I had a powerful rush of blueberries to the nostrils.  The beer has a wonderful lactic quality to it, slight barnyard funk, and a very, very minor touch of acetic acid.  Certainly, this nose is absolute perfection for a lambik, tart but not painfully so.  The mouthfeel is divine, not champagne-like but also nowhere near flat.  I used to prefer my lambik with a lot of carbonation, but this is just right.  Theres a light berry sweetness leading the rush of flavors.  The lactic tartness doesnt come in until the middle of the palate, giving the mind plenty of time to reflect on what its like to taste a delicious blueberry cheesecake slice.  The back of the palate is hit with the funk, the sour, and somehow, the lasting taste of blueberry.  In the end, I am left wondering what else a person could possibly want from this beer.  It perfectly melds rich and luscious fruit flavors with a tart but balanced palate, and it drinks really smoothly.  Cantillon has reached true beer nirvana, and Im grateful for the opportunity to drink such a (relatively) fresh and fine example.

2010 Vintage. Another huge thanks to daknole! Bottle pours deep red with a pink head.  Aroma is full of lactic goodness.  Big sour berry notes, with blueberry leading the forefront, leather, hay, bandaid, and a touch acetic (white vinegar).  Overall body is moderate with crisp, mouthwatering acidity.  White whale slain! I probably would have given it a 5 if it didnt come after a 50th anniversary 3 fonteinen.

thanks to sparky for shareing this one! batch 4 09. nice brew, fruity and just a mild sourness, not overpowering. very entcing appearance and aroma. looking forward to trying some of the fruitier batches!

8/26/2008.  750mL, 2007 Batch 2 shared by pepsican.  Hazy purplish pink with  a one finger eggshell head, good retention.  Definite aroma of tart blueberries, leather, vinegar, and some lemon.  Flavor is not as tart as the first batch, though still pretty tart and acidic that peaked at a 6.  Bone dry.  Light to moderate carbonation with a light body.  Great!  I liked this better than batch 1.
user_location: Ocean Beach, San Diego, California, USA

text:
Batch 6
Aroma is tons of lactic sourness, funk, and faint blueberry.  Absolutely beautiful.  Sour, funky, fruity, and insanely complex nose.
Taste is stongly sour blueberries, funk, creamy, dense some fruit skins, bitterness from the hops I would assume.  So crazy good.
Balanced, sour, and complex.
Finish is sour, lemony, and lactic.

UPDATED: MAY 9, 2012 Thanks to Joey for bringing this to the LCBS 10.  The pour was ruby red with barnyard aromas.  This beer was smooth and not overly sour with tart blueberries and sour cherries dominating the scene.  A great beer.....
2009 batch II, 750ml re-rate courtesy of destructo.  Even better than I remembered it......
 re-rate Batch 7, 750 ml shared at Mikkelllers Bar in Copenhagen.  So smooth.

750 ml bottle poured a clear reddish purple with a lasting lavender head. Aromas of berries, straw, leather and light barnyard. Palate was light bodied and crisp with a dry lightly tart finish. Flavors of berries, strawlight leather and light barnyard funk with a crisp dry lightly tart lingering berry finish.

2009 Vintage. Only the cork notes this (not the label) so not sure which one it is. When poured, the carbonation and popping pink bubbles are literally audible. Super-pretty beer. Nose is honestly a little laid-back for what I was expecting, but still nice - acidic forest berries (though oddly, not necesarily blueberries) and sweet/sour apples with a background of musty hay and earth. Although, as it sits in the glassand loosens up, I leave for a potty break, come back in the room and I can smell the blueberries from 5 feet away. Ive never been able to smell a beer that clearly from that far away. Taste is sublime. Honestly, not really a fault. The blueberry is forefront, and its that real "crushed them in my fingertips while stumbling on a blueberry patch in the woods" taste, slight woodiness and then a fantastic tart, funkiness to finish. This was a white whale for me that I sat on as long as humanly possible and was worth the wait and the hype. Great job.

Had this at a tasting at the abode of, "hannont". I dont know which, "vintage" this was, but after the bottles we had previously that night, Im surprised I the where-with-all to rate it!  Colour... dark orange with no head. Nose... man thats one funky ass b*#@%!! Palate...PUCKER MY KNICKERS!! An acetic blueberry fest in a glass! Tastes like a crushed Darrows and Spartans (blueberry varieties) with one BIG vinegar chaser. Gotta be one of the best lambics Ive ever had! HOO-AH!!

Bottle. First 2007 vintage. Huge thanks to anders37 for this one! Deep unclear red with a big orange-pinkish head. Aroma of barnyard, fruits (berries and more), some citrus and leathery notes. Wonderfully rounded sour flavor with berries, some lemons and wood. Medium-bodied, great soft mouthfeel. An awesome fruit lambic, with insane drinkabilty. Need more!

UPDATED: JAN 1, 2013 Huge thanks to Scott, on this one! Thanks for your generosity! Pours a deep cloudy purple with a pinkish purple head that dissipates quickly to the edges. Aroma is full of nice tart blueberries that grows in tartness and also has a bit of backing funk. The flavor starts slightly sweet with blueberries but quickly grows in tartness to quite a sour finish. There is a nice slight funky backing.

Bottle: Poured a deep murky blue-ish color lambic with a large enough foamy head with good retention and some good lacing. Aroma of funky notes with well balance sourness and some light blueberry notes is quiet special and intriguing. Taste is a nice enough mix between some light sour blueberries with some well balanced barnyard notes with good sour notes. All elements are well balanced and provided great enjoyment. Body was quite full with limited filtration and good carbonation.

Must emphasise that I dont know the vintage but I would like to say a massive thank you to Mes for the courtesy of forwarding me his glass and also to Magic Dave for a glass I had at his tastings evening. 

Very soft acidic levels, probably the best acidic levels in a lambic Ive ever had. Excellent balance, Good cherry-red appearance, lacing is good, tart, blueberries fantastic sour notes,, excellent bitterness, dry finish, very sour and tart and funky but what an amazing blend! This is one of the best beers Ive ever had. Thank you so much and special thank you for Jean for the Cantillon experience I had yesterday.

Bottle courtesy of dkachur from papsoe on 04/17/2010 at the 11th Richmond RateBeer Gathering. 2007 Vintage (batch 2). Cloudy red body with a small off-white head. Sweet blueberry and tart aroma. Big tart flavor with light blueberry. Light body with high carbonation.

Bottle (vintage 2007). Red, slightly muddy, with a thin white head. Strong berry aroma, however it reminds me of raspberries instead of blueberries. Very sour aroma, but also a note of sweet black currant candies. The flavour is very sour and bone dry. I think the very sour taste overpowers the flavour compounds, that may be there. Very interesting, but maybe a bit too sour for my taste.

A little hazy yellow/red colored beer, with a small beige head. The aroma of sour with wood, cookies and fruits. The taste is also sour notes of wood. There are fruits like berries with cookies in the back. The aftertaste has sourness with bitter.

Bottle, tfs Menno! Reddish brown pinkish pour, no head.
Aroma is intense and sharp brett with lots of fruit, some cherry, apple and blueberry, quickly becomes more subtle after the initial shock.
Flavour is extreme sourness but somehow in a smooth sort of way. Lots of brett, hint of above fruits.

375 ml Batch 6 courtesy of Daknole !!

A: pours an amazing deep purple, with a cream and purple colored small head. Able to see through the beer when held to the light.

S: smells of the distinct cantillon funk. Pure lambic all the way. Notes of lactic acid, freshly picked tart blueberries/raspberries. Musty wet hay, earthy horseblanket funk.

T: similar to the smell in that its cantillon all the way. Tart Blueberries, lacto, earthiness, light oak, tannic blueberry skins, very vinous and similar to red wine. Finishes nice and dry.

M: extremely drinkable. Not too berry sweet and not way too sour either. Great lively mouthfeel with perfect carbonation. Finishes crisp and dry with a great lingering tannic blueberry and sour lambic flavor.

D: could drink this all day everyday if I didnt end up with massive heartburn !

Bottle, thanks for sharing, Menno! Pours an almost clear dark orange color with a thin white head. Aroma of brett, oak, berries and balsamic vinegar. Flavor is sour, oak, some fruits and citrus. Quite sharp. Watery texture and lively carbonation. Nice brew.

375 ml.  no head, dark purple color.  I wanted to try this one for a while.  Although it was ok it dod not meet my expectations.  Strong band-aid taste along with a light blueberry taste.  Kind of wonder if I got an improper cellared bottle.  I will seek out another bottle.

UPDATED: DEC 31, 2015 Bottle 2005/2011.Rating #500@KØLF ,thanks yngwie. Pours amber orange with an off-white head.Aroma is funky,fruity,barnyard and blueberries.Flavor is sour ,blueberries ,very nice funk and barnyard.Complex woody and cellar notes.Very nice subtle blueberry lambik.

Bottle 2010 Vintage. Pours a brilliant dark purple with a smallish light cream / purple coloured head. Head vanished to leave just the smallest layer of foam. Minimal lacing. Great looking beer. Aromas are amazing. Lots of funk, some acidity and plenty of tatness from the blueberries. Aromas pick up as it warms slightly Great stuff. Flavours pretty much follow script with lots of funk and tartness from the berries. Minimal furit sweetness initially but perhaps just a little near the end. Mouthfeel is lively and full. Wonderful beer. Cant thank Papsoe enough for sending the half way around the world. Cheers

Bottle. Deep red pour, quite opaque and shiny. Modest pink head with nice retention. Aroma is an interesting mix of tartness and various sweet and sour berries. Lots of barnyard, leather and a little horse. Also lots of blueberries (obviously), strawberry and raspberry. Extremely fresh, complex and interesting. Taste is fairly highly sour with some sweetness as well. Little bitterness. Lots of blueberry, raspberry, sugar, malt and some barnyard-ish flavours as well. Also sour tart, apples, pears and some faint mango. The beer is almost perfectly balanced and contains the many flavours and aromas masterfully. A very, very good beer!

This was a very fun beer. It pours a purple color with a pinkish purple head. The aroma is tart and funky with blueberries, hay, leather, and horseblanket. The flavor is very tart, almost sour with blueberries, strawberries, cranberries, and a real depth of funkiness with cheese, barnyard, leather, and a touch of red wine vinegar. Truly, a one of a kind!

Bottle shared by Sparky, holy crap thanks a ton Eric! 
Pours a pinkish purple with a light pink head. Aroma is sour, blueberries, funk, horse blanket, acids, fruits, and a touch of cough syrup. Flavor is horseblanket, blueberries, a touch of tongue numbing acidic cough medicine, cheek numbing fruits and acids tantalize the palate. Different than I expected, but a unique world class beer for sure. Good stuff!

750mL bottle, 2007 Vintage (batch 2) . Pop the cap and the cork works itself up the beck and jumps out.  Pours with a bug head that fades quickly.  Thick purple color, beautiful.  Lots of sediment in the beer makes it hard to see through.  Aroma is all that great tart and sour lemon signature Cantillon.  The comes a second wave of blueberry perfume, light and natural.  Sweet juicy berry than they way of what is the Cantillon gueze. Flavor has the two characters mix very well, berry dies down and tart gueze comes out.  Long and sour, dry finish.

text:
UPDATED: JAN 12, 2013 This is a stunningly good looking beer. It has a deep red/purple pour with a beautiful pink head. Possibly the best looking beer Ive ever seen. Aroma has a lot of the classic Cantillon tartness, lots of barnyard, horse blanket, fresh blueberries, strong oak notes, small hints of mint, forrest berries, yeast. I really love the berries in this one. The taste has a good deal of sourness, oak and yeast and of course, a lot of nice blueberries. There is a fantastic balance between the tartness from the yeast and the oak, and the fresh sweetness from the blueberries. As is warms, the beer gets more of the fruity notes, creating an even more sophisticated balance between sweet and sour. Dry finish along with a really nice carbonation level. This is truly a good beer.

Vintage 2007. Deep red pour. Aroma is not as fruity as the 10, more tart, a small amount of blueberries funny enough, lots of læder, barnyard, brett, horse, Torben, oak and vanilla. Taste is insanely tart and dry. Not much fruit or sweetness, just bone dry and tart. A decent oak quality. Maybe hints of blueberry, marzipan and vanilla. Doesnt have the balancing sweetness like the 2010. 
9-5-7-4-14=3.9
Vintages 2011/2012 had these side-by-side in fall 2012, and the 2012 was without a doubt the best. Amazing fresh and sweet blueberry nose and velvety and sweet berry note that melded amazingly with the not so old lambic. The 2011 was very different in the base lambic, much more intensely barnyardy and bretty. The berries were more subdued, although still evident. The 2012 is by far the best vinage Ive had!

"I will get the Blåbær for you direct from the cask."

Up the stairs to the barrel room he scampers. The sound of a mallet. He reappears with a glass.

Its deep purple, lighter around the edges, and still. Blueberries, thick in flavor, yet dry and lightly tart. I believe this is for Batch 2 of 2010. Not yet sour or funky, but the taste finishes on a note of oak.

Despite the stillness, Blåbær is thicker than the still Rosé de Gambrinus I had next to it. In fact its almost creamy. This is already a knockout. I wouldnt have the patience to bottle this and then let it referment, but thats why he works for Cantillon and Im the one writing the review.

text: Flaske 0,375l delt med Rune 19 Mai 10: 2009 årgang - batch 4. Fargen er mørk kirsebær med et høyt lyserødt skum. Frisk & syrlig aroma. Smaken i samme gate. Litt uvariert. Ikke noe klart blåbærpreg.

75cl Bottle at home, Vintage 2010 (Batch 6). This is the best bottle of beer that I have ever had. I really could not find any reason to mark it down in any of the five sections. Aroma was very very funky and filled with farmyard smells. Appearance, doubt it could get any better. Taste, really fruity lambic with blueberrys lasting long into the finish. The sourness is there but its not harsh. Palate is soft and light, Carbonation is soft. Huge, massive thanks to Anker for this!!!!!!!

2010 Bottle. With all the hype I didnt think this beer could impress. It did.
Pours opaquely blue with a pink head and a funky sour nose nose. Earthy, leather, lactic sour taste. Some tart sweetness  with a massive fruity body that doesnt thin out. Light to medium carbonation. Absolutely fantastic.

Corked and capped 375 mL bottle courtesy of Papsoe. Thanks! Batch 2-2007. Shared at the 11th Richmond Ratebeer Gathering, 4/17/10. Pours a hazy orange-red color with a thin fizzy head that fades quickly. Aroma of dry, tart berry notes with a mild funkiness. Some earthy notes and a mildy sweet essence in the finish. The taste is tart and dry with lots of blueberries, cherries and other berries. Some citrusy notes and a mild funkiness in the finish. Medium bodied, smooth with moderate carbonation. Medium bodied. Very nice lambic.

UPDATED: MAR 25, 2012 Batch 4 drank next to Upland Blueberry and Ithaca LeBlue. Most unique looking beer Ive seen, a smooth maroon-purple color with a puffy strawberry milkshake head. Cantillon nose, lots of bright fruit and acidity with wheat and a bit of stable.The blueberry connects through the acidity and is reminiscent of berry-lambics, a framboise most so. Flavor is similar though a bit less complex, the blueberry a bit stronger and sweeter, rather skin-like, accented by how dry it is. The carbonation is soft enough to appreciate the berry sweetness in balance with the lambic base. Id prefer a bit more blueberry in the nose and more stable in the flavor, and on the whole, comes off as Cantillon does blueberry (unlike the Lamnivus). Still excellent though, destroying the other two blueberry sours we had next to this.09 currently showing Cantillon phenolics with the flabby, sticky body.

2009 Batch 4, huge thanks to Kevin for sharing this one!

A-pours a dark maroon color, completely opaque with a light purple head that is pretty dense.

S-hint of tart cranberry immediately taken over by a cheesy barnyard funk. light acidity behind with a good sweet completely unripened fruit aroma, cranberry, blueberries and raspberry with a nice tartness to it.

T-the taste is great, nice sour and acidity. the cranberries and raspberries are up front, no where near ripe with that tartness that accompanies fruit of that nature. a light barnyard funkiness, not as present as the nose, with an astringent tartness and sublte blueberry flavor finishing it out.

M-soft feel to it, nice carbonation, syrupy body with a good crisp finish to balance and slightly astringent.

D-great balance, fantastic beer, excellent fruit appearance with perfect acidity and tartness, light barnyard funk adds complexity and works in very well.

2009 Vintage.  First off, thanks for StFun for sending this epic beer my way!  Pour was hazy light blue/purple, medium carbonation and an aroma of funk, mellow fruit and mildly sour aroma.  Flavor was just unreal, light sour bite right off the bat, then mellow blueberry and finshed creamy and tart on the finish.  I can only hope to get another bottle of this someday.

UPDATED: AUG 5, 2010 750 ml bottle graciously shared by beastiefan2k. 2007 Vintage (Batch 2). Pour is a hazed ruby red dark orange with a 1/2 inch whitish pink head.  Aroma of floral (lavender almost) wood, some cheesy funk, and the sweet sour blueberry. Taste is sharp lactic sour, lemon citrus, blueberry fruit, and finishing with some of the tannic wood. Really tart, really bright acidity. Lemon, citrus rind, really bright and beautiful.  Palate is medium bodied, lightish carbonation and a lingering dry tart mineral woody finish. Thanks Eugene, I have been dying to try this for a long time.

Sample of vintage 2010 offered me by a swedish beerrater, thanx.
Purple with a pink head. Aroma moderate to heavy sour with lots of blueberry and notes of oak. Flavor of sour blueberries and wood. Medium body. Fantastic. I must  buy a bottle a.s.a.p.

Batch # 4  Courtesy of ygtbsm94.  Thanks for sharing this gem, Brad!  Purple, thick pink cream head (great cobweb lacing).  Deep soured funky blueberry aromas ride a hearty undercurrent of lemon oak and old cheese.  Soft milky soured blueberry-barnyard flavors are well balanced on swirls of musty barrel and citrus tones throughout.  Medium bodied, medium carbonation, funked sour berry finish.  Just an unbelievable beer

UPDATED: JUL 28, 2013 2009 375ml bottle opened January 2010
A: Rich reddish-purple body with a lively, bubbly pink head. Held on for quite some time before receding. Never quite died down though. Nice sticky, spotty lacing.
S: Bold, sweet blueberries. Light funky-tartness. Subtle vinegar undertones.
T: Absolutely incredible. The blueberries here are very refined. In general they give off a slightly sweet character, but are deliciously tart and sour as well. There is a nice lambic acidity that contributes an earthy, vinegar funk to round out this delightful beverage.
M: Light bodied with a nice effervescent, yet restrained carbonation level. Smooth with a nice crisp dry finish. The only knock on this here is the blueberry sludge, which I am assuming is left over blueberry skins which settled into the last sip of the glass. Slightly off putting, but a marginal flaw at most.
O: Out of this world. This really was a treat. To cap off the tasting with this was a superb decision. Now I just have to find more ammo to get more of this!

Huge thanks to Papsoe for trading this absolute gem to me.  Pours a beautiful pinkish color, and is absolutely spot-on what Ive come to expect from Cantillon.  A delicious tartness thats rounded out nicely and finishes incredibly smoothly.  The blueberries come out mostly in the nose, not so much in the flavor.

Bottle (thanks to Tweety for sharing)... [Vintage 2007 Batch 2]...  Poured maroonish with a pinnkish head.  Nose had blueberries and yeast funk.  Very earthy. herbal leaf tones, lots of blueberry flavors, yeast dryness and a tart and sour finish.
Bottle 2009. Incredible beer. Lots of berry taste with nice acidic notes. Well balanced. Give me one more!

bottle thanks to OteyJ
Pours a Dark purple, opaque, pink cotton candy head.  Aroma is concentrated blueberry fruit, red currant, acetic acid, musty sourness, rustic.  
Flavor explodes in my mouth, sour blueberry, tannic blueberry skins lend some bitter sourness, extremely sour, a bit of lacto sourness as well.  Creamy yet titillatingly effervescent.

09 bottle, big thanks to oteyj. Pours a gorgeous deep purplish burgundy with a dark rose colored, frothy head. Aroma is incredible; lots of sour blueberry, funk, some deep vinous notes, musty wood, wet hay, and currants. Flavor is hugely sour, with blueberry and lemon, more funky wood, and amazing tannic notes that seem to be from the blueberrys skin at the finish. Palate has just the right amount of well apportioned effervescence, and the massive tartness fades nicely into a finish that makes the drinker long for another sip. And I will certainly oblige and give in to that desire. Im done rating- I need to drink this now.

Rating #1000. Been waiting a long time for this one- thanks Bo. Dark purple ruby pour with a one finger pink head. The aroma is simply otherworldly. Massive funk, horse taint, hay, farm, currant, and blueberry. My dear lord. Huge sour notes- lactic and acetic acids with one of the best funk profiles Ive ever encountered. Blueberry and currant round out the fruit profile in the most wondrous way. Aftertaste of tannic blueberry skins. The palate is massively attenuated, dry, and creamy in its effervescence. The best beer Ive ever had.

UPDATED: FEB 2, 2016 Sampled at DC Epic Sour Tasting 2010.  So glad I got to try three different batches of this.  Batch 1 - The best, in my opinion.  Pours a totally clear, orange amber with a soft white head.  Nose is very musty, like a blueberry muffin thats molded over, grassy, farm, dust, spice, celery.  Flavor is nice, tart, sour, lemony, berry skins, grassy, hay, dusty, spices, white pepper.  Very puckering, full bodied, tart without being too acidic.  This is a total gueze and very nice.  Batch 2 - The first thing you notice is that the color is totally different.  This glass is a hazy purple, nearly opaque.  The aroma is more musty and has a lot more berry.  Flavor has TONS more berry, more funk but more acid too.  Almost jammy.  Plenty of Band Aid in both nose and flavor too.  Batch 3 - Crystal clear pink color.  Three batches, three totally different looks.  The flavor and nose are both weaker than batch 2 and batch 1 for that matter.  This is not nearly as funky as batch 2 either.  This was basically like drinking 3 different beers.  Im certainly not complaining though...*****Sampled the 2011 vintage in January 2016.  Nose you could smell all day long.  Nice berry but also plenty of Cantillon character.

UPDATED: FEB 20, 2011 Had the first three batches of this at the DC epic sour tasting.  This rating of 4.3 is for 2007 first batch (so technically batch 2 overall).  Batch 1 rating:  thanks to ygtbsm94!  clear, light orange witha very small white lace on the edge.  Nose isnt much blueberry but noticeable since I knew what to look for.  Taste is quite geuze like.  Super smooth on the palate although quite sour.  Definitely more geuze like than fruit lambic.  Excellent brew. 4.0      Batch 2 rating:  Thanks to tarheels86.  Totally different!  Deep ruby pour, slightly murky.  YOu can actually get blueberry in the nose.  Is much more acetic.  Very similar sour level to the cantillon kriek.  Really really nice sour.  Much more acetic and much more blueberry than the batch 1.  Very pleasant and drinkable. 4.4  Batch 3 rating:  thanks to ygtbsm94.  mellowed out.  Much better head and retention.  Definitely increased carbonation from batch 2, though softer mouthfeel, less blueberry, and less body.  3.9  Batch 5 rating bottle thanks to wavers1.  Poured a deep ruby with a light pink, thin head.  Nose is tart berry and apparent sourness.  If blind, I wouldnt have placed it as blueberry alone.  More mixed cherry/blackberry. Funk.  Taste was not as sour/funky as nose indicates, but very tasty and balanced.  Mouthfeel was smooth, not as tart, balanced between full berry flavor, tartness, and more berry.  Very berry.  Probably the most fruit of the batches that I have had.  9 4 8 4 16= 4.1    Batch 6 rating: bottle thanks to Ryan.  Best of the 5 Ive had.  Deep ruby  red/pink pour with a large frothy pink head.  Aroma is a pungent sour blueberry.  This is batch 2 on steroids.  More fruit and more sour than batch 2, which was my previous favorite.  The taste is blueberry skins, bitter rind, tannins.  Most of the blueberry comes at the end.  Incredibly sour and fruity.  9 4 10 5 19=4.7

All 750 ml bottles at DC Epic Sour Tasting 2010.  

2005 vintage (batch 1), courtesy of ygtbsm94, thank you sir: Hazy light purple, 3 bubble edge head.  Aroma caused minor palpitations which resolved spontaneously; dust, must and lemon.  Taste was dry and dusty, not much fruit except for a hint in the finish.  Full body.  Great character and complexity.  Like a classic geuze more than a fruit lambic.  My favorite of the three; rating is for this bottle. 4.3

2007 vintage (batch 2), courtesy of tarhels86, on a detour from brewing with Struise, thanks!  Deep purple color, fizzy pink head.  Aroma is lighter and more subtle.  More fruit taste, slightly less sour, with no dust or must.  Very good. 4.2

2007 vintage (batch 3), courtesy of ytgbsm94, whom I cant thank enough.  Very slightly less purple than batch 2, with a faint aroma of lemon rind and not much else.  Taste is blueberries, bread.  Nice. 3.9

UPDATED: JUL 8, 2012 750mL 2005 Batch 1 gold foil courtesy of ygtbsm94. This was my favorite batch. Totally unreal. Pours a light orange with a bubbly white head. Clear in initial pour but insanely opaque grapefruit juice color with the yeast. Aroma is subdued blueberry muffin, unblended lambic citrus, funk, sour fruits. Taste is slight blueberries, unwashed, full of blueberry skins, lots of bright citrus and grapefruit rind that takes over and makes the blueberry very subdued. Overall is very sour and light bodied.   
9/4/9/5/16
750mL 2007-1 Batch 2 black foil courtesy of madsberg. This is a totally different lambic all together. This pours like a kriek that is on crack- straight up opaque purple with a billowing purple head that is insane. Blueberry seeds tumble into the champagne flute. Nose is full of band-aid, goes almost chemical, and has some baked cherry pie that comes through if you give it a chance. Taste is more acidic, full of sour cherries, blueberry skins. Way different. Blind tasting either batch 1 or batch 2 I would not put as a blueberry lambic. I would put batch 1 as unblended, and 2 as a kriek.    
7/5/8/4/15
750mL 2007-2 Batch 3 gold foil courtesy of ygtbsm94. This is where I think Jeppe was able to find a happy medium between batch 1 and 2. This pours a cloudy pink with less of a pink head. Aroma has no band-aid and has more blueberry muffin, brine, cheese, funk, and overall less intense than batch 2. Taste is considerably more tart, full of lacto, more acidic. 
9/4/8/4/15
Im scoring batch 1 as it was my favorite rather than averaging all of them together. 375mL 2010 ed thanks to madsberg. Pours clear bloody ruby to purple. Pink head. Sucret, medicinal nose. Taste is anesthetic, medicinal, very tangy, salty, berry heavy, loads of dusty blueberry skins. 3.9 level overall. 7/8/2012 7/4/8/4/16=3.9

375 bottle, vintage 2009, batch 4, bought at Ølbutikken in Copenhagen almost a year ago. Small, pink-reddish head atop of an opaque, dark-red coloured body. Acid berries to the nose, quite mild. Tart and sweet berries in flavour, more in the direction of redcurrant than blueberries. Ends modest bittersweet and dry (shared with Finn, Tromsø 19.05.2010).

UPDATED: MAR 20, 2011 Bottle of the 09 (batch 5, I think).  Aroma is straight horse blanket and blueberries.  Par for the course for Cantillon - dry with bracing acidity.  It picks up a firm tannin finish from the blueberry skins slightly reminiscent of a red wine.  Pretty nice, at any rate. Update:  the tannins are softening, a bit more dried flowers in the aroma.  Still pretty nice.

75cl Batch 3 bottle compliments of Papsoe; Tak Henrik! Celebrating Mothers Day at home with family. Clear appearance with colours like a sparkling rosé with cranberry hues. Medium sized off-white head. BUSY aroma with blueberries that are tart and sweet plus some oak notes and a little vinegar that makes your mouth water (maybe some barnyard too?). Flavour is more of the aroma but I like it because it sticks more to the tart sourness than the vinegar side of the house. I also get some spicy, charred notes from somewhere. Not sure if that is a character of this batch but it avoids being "too sour".

Bottle. Vintage 2007, batch 2. Thanks to Enjoyit. Pours a murky reddish brown with a pinkish head. Aroma is sour and a bit fruity. Notes of stable. Quite nice. Flavour is very sour. Remote notes of blueberries, but they almost drown in the sourness. Finish is dry and sour, with perfumy notes, and with the blueberries a little more distinct than in the initial flavour, but still drowning in the sourness. I like it when the fruity notes in a beer are just hinted, but this didnt work for me. Overall just too sour for me to appreciate it fully. 07-05-10.

Bottle 2007 vintage batch 2 at Ølkonsortiet. Thank you Svend for letting an ignorant taste this rare gem. Sorry but I don´t get this one. Redorange muddy and unclear colour very little white head. Aroma sour barnyard, manure, not very pleasant. Taste sour, sour sour, the blueberries can hardly be detected. I think it´s a quite onedimensional beeer, not much else than a very sour beer.

damn, dak! 2/7/2010. 2009 vintage. 

blurple colored with an aggressive off white head. the bottom gets murky and further funky.

wow! aromas as follows... vinegar ( and loads of it), freezer burn, blueberry, grass, vomit, rotten garbage, chocolate peppers (chlorophyll), earth, yeast, umami, funky wet concrete and some wood. insanely disgusting yet scrumptious. 

the blueberry really becomes pronounced in the flavor. and, it tastes a lot like bile and vomit....mmm!

crisp carbonation adds to the puckering in the cheeks....wow! 9/5/9/5/19/4.7

Hell yeah, 1700 ratings!  Im officially a massive beer nerd!  375ml bottle from soulforpeanuts on BA, who is the man. Thanks, Rick! This bottle was from Batch 5, I believe, with 2009 and what looks like a 2 printed on the bottle.

Blåbær (Im still not 100% sure how to say the name of this beer) pours a dark but fairly clear purplish color, really stunning, with a one-finger head that has pinkish hues. This is not the appearance I expected after having had other blueberry beers. I like it a lot.

Aroma is very nice, but not a standout for a Cantillon fruit lambic. Cantillons signature yeast is ever-present. Bretty funk and lactic notes as well as a substantial blueberry presence.

The flavor is intense sour blueberries (not too sour though) and a little funk. I got some grape flavors in there as well, and definitely some vinegar notes. I poured it out in 3 increments, and I feel like the flavor got more intense toward the bottom of the bottle.

The palate is somewhat typical for a Cantillon fruit lambic, which is to say its awesome. Theres really a great tingling that you get on the mouthfeel that almost chokes you up. That is a very good thing. Body is medium and mouthfeel is lively. Medium level of acidity for the style.

Very drinkable. I kept coming back for another sip, and my girlfriend, who I shared this with, had to get me to slow down so she could have some. What an excellent beer. I dont know if I could rank it over some of the Lou Pepe beers with age on them, but then again, this beer could probably be pretty damn incredible with age too. Looking forward to trying this one again.

Sampled at the Richmond Eleventh. Pours a beautiful murky purple with pink head ring.  Looks like melted raspberry sherbet. Fantastic tangy acidic nose.  Flavors of raspberry and blueberry and sour.  VERY nice beer.

(Sample Date: 4/17/2010   Source:Dkachur)   Brett sourness with berries and hint of alcohol. Cloudy dark amber brown with little head. Quite sour with wood and caramelized sugars in the background. Nice complexity between sourness and earthy sweetness. Finish is dry and tart. Very nice!

Batch 2, 2007, courtesy of dkachur at Richmond Gathering 11.  Pours a slightly murky pinkish reddish color.  Aroma horeseblanket, dusty lemon, pixie dust.  Flavor is horseblanket, cheddar cheese, muddy fruit,  puckering sour finish.  As usual, fantastic brew from these guys.

Flaske, batch 5: Dybrød øl med en fin karbonering. Eddike og en smule stald i duften, men desværre næsten ingen blåbær. Smagen er fin men igen mangler der blåbær. En smule skuffende ovenpå Lou Pepe Kriek, men stadig en fin øl og en kewl historie til den. Men flere blåbær tak.

UPDATED: APR 10, 2010 Batch 5, small bottle.  Pours a light purple with a pink head.  Really a cool looking beer.  Smells tart with a lot of non-descript berries going on, blueberries is the only one I can pick out but its not too strong.  It is mildly carbonated.  Blueberries come through much stronger on the taste and linger after drinking.  The beer is also rather funky and not too sour.  Another great beer from Cantillon
Iam not found of Gueuze but this ones pretty cool. Aroma of woods and blueberries and very good drinkability.  This is quite a tasty beer,

This review is of a Batch 4 bottle (2009)

A: The pour is a fantastic looking deep purple color with a fluffy pink head on top.

S: The nose is certainly very fruity, but I dont necessarily detect a lot of blueberries. There are some great cherry, raspberry, and a mixture of other tart berries. There is also a lot of lactic tartness, but not as much in the way of funk or wood as you usually expect from Cantillon.

T: Like the nose, the fruit is really the star of the show in this beer. A mix of indistinguishable tart berries really hits you up front. The oak comes through a bit more in the flavor, but is not overpowering. While I had been noting a lack of blueberry flavor, they really come out on the finish.

M: The body is medium to full with a nice tingly carbonation on the tongue.

D: This is one of the most fruit forward lambics/wild ales Ive come across. I really enjoyed the balance of the fruit and the traditional funk and sourness.
bottle, thanks to thirdeye11, ruby red grapefruit color with lots of funky berry and pepper aromas, flavors are acidic, blueberry is quite tart, more peppery wood

Again, big thanks to Jack for this.  Poured a murky purple color with a light pink head.  Aroma was cherry, vinegar, classic funk and berries.  Taste was much the same, nice big vinegar bit with tart cherry and blueberry on the back end.  A nice tart acidic bite rounded out the flavors.  I think this may have been batch 4, as the fruit was coming through quite a bit.

bottle thanks to thirdeye11.  poured purpleish with a pinkish head.  aroma was raspberry, cherry, tart, and some barrel notes???  flavor was pretty much the same and really funky.  medium body with low carbonation.  very good stuff.

( 375 bottle vintage 2009 of unknown batch thanks to BA bosse) Pours beautiful deep red with ring of bubbles. Nose of tart blueberry, cherry, extremely funky. Taste of blueberries, sweetness, tart cherries, funk with a very dry finish.

One of the most hyped up beers for me that I liked well enough, but this wasnt a masterpiece. Not sure if it needed more age, or the vintage just wasnt my favorite. Would love to try again.

Bottle courtesy of a generous RB at tpd975s throwdown, December 2009. Pours a reddish to pink amber color with thin off-white head. Aroma is sour and funky with notes of fresh berries, vinegar, overripe cherries, oak, hints of smoke. Flavor is about the same with stronger fruit notes and more oak and funk. Medium body with a pleasing berry funk finish.

Bottle thanks to callmemickey.  I believe this is batch 4 or 5.  Pours solid purple with beautiful pink bubbly head that lingers for minutes.  Aroma is easily dominated by blueberry, but has some great lemon and orange along with earthy funk/horse blanket.  Taste is mild honey sweetness then great tartness.  A little vanilla on the finish but then a lingering blackberry taste on the tongue.  Great tartness, well balanced and good carbonation.  Another incredible lambic from Cantillon.

2009 bottle thanks to thirdeye11.  poured purple with a pink head.  nose is blueberries, funk and wood.  very smooth on the palate with a flavor of sour blueberries and a slightly sour blueberry finish.

From notes. Bright ruby/red/pink, small pink head. Beautiful nose- earthy barn funk, wild blueberries, nice acidity and tartness, subtle dry wood. Berries are more subdued initially, but come back as it warms. Great balance of funk, sour, and berries. Medium body, sparkling yet juicy, easy to drink. Awesome.

UPDATED: DEC 26, 2012 2009 bottle (unsure which batch) generously shared by thirdeye11. Pours with a small pink head over a hazy, blueberry juice colored body. Aroma of funk, manure, grass, wild berries, and some tannic notes. A lot more funky and less fruit driven than I was expecting. Taste is quite sour with blueberry skins, and nice clean acidity. Dry, sour and light bodied. 7/4/9/4/15: 3.9  2005 Batch 1 Bottle thanks to alen. Pours with a crystal clear deep peach hue with a small white head. Aromas are of minerals, funky, complex, with medium fruit. Flavors are extremely sour, tart, fruity, berry, wood. Rustic, a touch messy, but tasty. Tart and acidic, puckering mouthfeel with lively bubbles and a dry finish.

2009 vintage.  Pours a beautiful dark plum color with dark purplish mahogany edges and a one finger frothy pinkish/plum head that quickly dissipates into a miniscule off white ring that eventually fades as throughout the duration of the glass.

Earthy funky musty aroma with a good bit of barnyard horseblanlet character. Lots of sweet vinous dark fruit notes especially bluberry of course as well as some grape and plum.

Slightly tart and very puckering with a lot of musty barnyard funk. Not very acidic with a lot of earthy oaky tannis. Lots of dark fruit notes that adds to the sweet vinous, vinegary character. The blueberries really come through as well as some grape, plum and fig. Very complex and well balanced. This beer is surprisingly drinkable considering how complex and funky it is. I wish I could drink this again. Highly recommends!

2009 vintage (batch 4)

A hazy reddish pink color with a small pink head that settles fairly quickly and leaves a ring of lacings.

The first thing to appear  in the smell is Cantillons funky house character of hay, earth and a hint of vinegar. Then, the fruit aromas appear - both tart green apples and ripe (almost overripe and fermenting) red apples, and fragile yet prominent notes of blueberries. Everything feels very rustic and genuine, no artificial fruit flavors in sight. Being a fruit lambic from Cantillon, the smell is very balanced and sober, not even close to harsh.

The taste showcases a flawless balance between tartness and sweetness, and again this beer feels relatively balanced and tidy. The sourness isnt as puckering as in some other beers from Cantillon. Instead it showcases an amazingly balanced complexity. The mild sweetness has a pleasant fruit character. Lots of aromas of apples, lemon peel and goose berries. Lots of blueberry flavors - but they are not overly prominent. At first, the blueberries has a somewhat sweet character and really give the beer a unique overall character. But heres lots of tartness going on which levels the sweetness, and in general the beer is quite sour. Hints of vinegar and lactic acid. Pleasant funky notes of wet hay, earth and brett. Hints of wheat. The finish has a very subtle grassy bitterness to it and nice oak barrel flavors. Hints of tart blueberries, minerals and funk lingers on in the mouth.

Moderate body and sparkling carbonation. Feels like a sparkling white wine in the mouth, but unfortunately the carbonation is slightly too exaggerated and it gets somewhat inharmonious. Dry finish.

A unique and really good beer. But some aspects of it arent as great as the overall character. It doesnt showcase the same "in your face-attitude" as some other beers from Cantillon. Instead, as noted above, its really well balanced and very complex. Despite its few kinks, a masterpiece.

Some brief notes about batch 5, released in the fall of 2009:

The same lovely color as batch 4. The smell is also very similar to the older batch, perhaps the blueberry aromas are slightly more prominent. The big difference lies in the mouthfeel and in the way the blueberries appear in the taste. The blueberries are slightly more pronounced, especially in the finish were they are very noticeable (and very tasty with a genuine and rustic character). This gives the beer a slightly new expression and I really enjoyed it. The level of carbonation is somewhat lower in this batch and the beers seems a little smoother. All in all, its still a great beer.

Serving type: bottle

(Copy of old Beer Advocate review)

2009 bottle.  Pours a deep, opaque blood red with a really pretty cotton candy, rosy head that settled into a soapy haze.  So pretty.  Tart and acidic on the nose.  Has a soft element that I really liken to 3 Fonteinen Hommage at about 1 year.  Soft blueberries and raspberries.  Pretty meaty.  Soft and quite well integrated in the mouth.  Deep blueberry skins and stems abound.  A little foresty, pretty wild, quite rich.  Brett isnt huge though its quite sour and funky.  Oak and soft acids are in the forefront along with the sour wild blueberries.  Really enjoyable.

UPDATED: JUN 16, 2011 Bottle from bbb63- BIG THANKS. Second batch of 2009.  Relatively new.  pours a violet with a pink head.  leaves a pink ring around the glass.   This is one of the most pleasantly funky beers Ive had.  Blueberry with a horseblanket, fresh washed stinky sock aroma, vacumn cleaner dust, fruit.  Really nice.  Impressed.  Flavor is a slightly tart blueberry, bready earthy funk.  Not overly funky or acidic, but very well balanced and approachable.  I would like some more sourness and funk, but there is no doubting that this is a well made beer.

375ml Bottle Pours out a deep maroon with some purple highs. Topped with a small head. Aroma of blueberry along with plenty of the tartness, a little funk, vanilla, and some oak. Flavor is more of the tart and sour blueberries along with some light sweetness. Thanks a ton Sam your the man. I never thought I would get to try this.

UPDATED: FEB 23, 2012 Pours a deep, jammy, garnet-tinged violet.  The head is thin, ultra-fine, and bright mauve in hue.  Huge barnyard funk on the nose, along with tart black current, and a sweet hint of blueberry.  Flavor compliments the nose, amplifies the funk, adds loganberry and woody notes.  The mouthfeel is smooth; but finishes sharp, tart, and dry.  A nicely balanced fruit/funk brew, and a privilege to enjoy.

UPDATED: NOV 11, 2014 Huge thanks to Alex (MasterSki) for opening this one at our wild/sour tasting. 2009 Batch 4, poured from 375ml bottle into Bells Tulip.

A - Pours purple/dark blue with a pink fluffy head. Lots of sticky lacing is left behind once the head dies down a bit. The look of this beer is unlike anything Ive ever seen...something to be seen, no doubt about it!

S - Blueberry funk/tart, mellow sweetness, and light acidic notes. Its hard to put into words the perfection of this blueberry lambic, so pardon me if I just comment how awesome it is by saying, "its awesome".

T - Well, what do you think it tastes like? Uh...blueberries? Yeah, Id say so. Sweet blueberries, sour blueberries, funky blueberries. However youd like your blueberries, this lambic dishes it out. A nice acidic bite but nothing too strong. This one stays pretty mellow when compared to the nose.

M - Light, nice fizzy carbonation that cover the palate well. This is a great beer to swish around on your mouth and enjoy slowly. A nice rich finish, that I really enjoy.

D - So easy to drink, I already want another all to myself!

Batch 2 bottle at PP Carlsbad. Murky amber tiny hue with a thin smattering of white foam. Nose is big blueberry with acidic tartness, light funk and vanilla, oaky wood. Flavor is tart and sour blueberries and other light fruits, uber tartness dominates, light bitterness, finishes dry. Medium body/ carbonation, prickly texture. A top line sour blueberry ale, all around solid flavor even though the sourness drowns out the blueberry near the end.

Batch #5

 Violet pink foamy head.

 Sour, dry, fruity aroma.

 Initially just sour, in a pleasent limited way, then the blue berry sets in. Symphonic. Ends in sweet distinct berry.

 Medium body, fizzy.

 Very nice. However, after a few sips the sourness kills the blueberry taste.

 Medium body, fizzy.

Purchased in Ølbutikken.

UPDATED: DEC 3, 2009 For the birth of my first child Hadley Matte. Batch 4. Pours with a slightly cloudy, rose body topped by a thin to medium thick head with some lacing. Its sour and tart with nice underlying blueberry that adds some sweetness. Light bodied, crisp and dry. One of my favorite for sure.

UPDATED: NOV 12, 2009 Placeholder until a re-rate. Had a bottle from what I believe was March 2009, Batch 4?. Very disappointing and nothing like I remembered. Now I need to drink a bottle from the cellar  (Batch 002) and hope to erase this bad memory.

2009 bottle.  A rich, gorgeous velvet purple pour and a pillowy crown of pink.  Blasts of blueberries and funk in the nose; beneath, vanilla, gritty fruit sugars, and minerals are just little accents on this massive, jammy juiciness, so rich and compelling atop the intimidating funk of cantillon.


Taut, punchy flavor of lemons and blueberries, tannins and oranges; the blueberries are so palpable that much like the freshest fruit they bring out hints of other fruits buried inside; the funk is way underneath this and plays a perfect complimenting role, which is much better to me than the confronting role it plays in foufone or saint lamvinus, for this purpose at least.  Its detailed, not complicated, and the blueberries shine; lightly salty afterward.

Tight, full palate, brisk and puckering, giving an almost rich chocolate like blueberry flavor in the finish; intricate and impressively harmonious.  Ty knew how bad i wanted this, thanks a ton buddy!

UPDATED: SEP 6, 2010 Finally! I couldnt wait any longer after getting this in a trade.
Batch 2 - 2007 - 375ml

A - Wow, Ive never seen a beer this color... As I pour this deep purple lambic almost 2 fingers of pink stained tan head rises and settles after a few seconds.

S - The second I started pouring this I could smell the blueberries. When youre nose deep in the glass there is a strong acidity and a nice healthy funk, lovely barnyard and cheese.

T - Frickin awesome. Not the sourest Cantillon Ive had, but definitely packs a punch. It blend very well with the funk going on as well. The blueberries are also the most present out of Cantillon fruit lambic that Ive had. It might just be in my head but I swear the blueberries also add to the sourness, as if they were picked early.

M/D - This one was carbonated pretty well and probably one of the only things I could find I didnt like about, and I was trying pretty hard. 
Rarity and price aside, I could drink this any day of the year, I would just need 30 minutes to lose myself in it.


Batch 4 -  2009 - 750mL

This is a pure funk bomb, tastes like a blueberry flavored band-aid. Fruit wasnt as present as I remembered, and this bottle was fresher... Too medicinal...

I was lucky enough to get me a couple of bottles of the 09 2nd batch. The aroma is unmistakably blue berry and a lot! After half a bottle, I somehow loose the track of the berry flavor. Still, a climax of a lambic.

An aroma of vinegar, funk, wood and cassis. Taste is of blueberries and cassis. Acidic at first, then fruity and dry in the finish. Its elegant and drinkable - the fruity character of those blueberries are really suitable for a fruit lambic!

Aroma of funk, oak, black currant and fruit. Appearance is dark red with almost no head. Flavor is sour and sweet with taste of blueberries, tart and black currant. Thickles in the mouth. Almost no carbonation. Overall an amazing beer with complex taste and interesting mouth feel.

Bottle shared kindly by fodog. Pours a gorgeous purple/magenta with a pink head. Stunning. Nose start soft fruity, currents, light tartness and a wash of honey tinged funk. Flavor start tart, a soft sour, fruity, berries, then the tannins come in. Bretty funk towards the finish with more berry, a touch acetic and finally a solid tartness. Soft, lush, dry without loosing the soft berry flavors. Fantastic!

I finally got a chance to try this beer, thanks Jeppe! The beer poured a hazy, deep amber almost crimson body, dense. Vigorour head formed, vibrant pint color that receeded quickly and left a full ring on the edge. The nose was very tart, earthy and a bit of exotic fruit. The taste...tart, tart, tart! Dont get me wrong, the taste is excellent. The blueberry notes are strong, fresh and wonderful. There is also some citrus and pepper on the tongue. If you take a look at the label, the face tells you the story of this beer. Tart yet wonderful. Well worth the effort to get it.

UPDATED: JUL 3, 2011 Sample from batch 4.  (7, 4, 8, 3, 16) total 3.8 (April 2009)

In all honesty I thought it would both smell and taste more blueberries than it did. 

The beer was still good with a nice balance between the sourness and sweetness from the fruits.


I must re-rate this one. The new rating is for a bottle of 2011 Vintage (batch 7)

I was a novice in terms of drinking Lambic when I drank batch 4 in April 2009.

The beer was tastier now, I felt more blueberries in both the aroma and taste. Someone mentioned the Swedish blueberry soup, Blåbärssoppa, I must say that was a good comparison besides the tartness that is quite spectacular in this beer. Very good beer but not as good and elegant as Cantillon Soleil de Minuit.

The bottle looks really good, the beer in the glass also. Very dark, dark red, modest turbid.  Starts very, very fruity, also quite sourish. Notes of berries and elder. Sourishness is increasing, finish very intense and warming, prickly and scratchy aftertaste. Very, very good! Thanks to Todeon for the bottle!

Shared at BCTC thanks to Miver. Pours a hazy/milky pinkish with little to no head.  Aroma of this wonderful sourness, funky and horsey.  Some of the blueberry character still there but mostly all consumed by the wild yeast.  Flavor was the same thing going on. So good yet so hard to explain.

Batch 4, 2009 vintage Poured a dark pinkish red into my Cantillon tumbler. Head was a huge light pink creamy wonder. Aromas of sour cherries,raspberries,blueberries,pepper, and some leather. Perfect balance of sour and fruit. Amazing beer. May someday I drink again.

375ml courtesy of Fiver29  thanks John!  Pours a cloudy purplish amber with a thin tan head.  The nose is barnyard dfunk, vinegar, aspirin and unripe fruit.  The taste is sour lemons, red wine vinegar, tart blueberry skin and light funk.  Puckeringly sour at first but that fades to a semi-sweet fruit finish.  Medium prickly mouthfeel.  Very good  - thanks again John!

Bottle shared by Sparky27...WOW!!!  Thanks again Eric!!!  2007 vintage produced a crystal raspberry pour with a fizzy eggshell head...pink/lavender hue.  Aroma is extreme barnyard, pungent lemon rind, vinegar, and funk.  Flavor is tart and puckering, with no real distinguishable blueberry present.  Got lockjaw with the first sip, but this either mellowed or my tongue acclimated to the sour.  Definitely more drinkable as it warmed.  Lively carbonation that ignited the palate.  Very good.

Bottle. 2007. Frothy white good mostly deminishing head. Wonderfull red colour. Very sour barnyard aroma. Berrys not very present alas. Powerfull sour acetic flavor. Again lacks berries-notes. Long great sour finish. Oily palate.

It says 2009 on the bottle, which I believe is from batch 4, purchased at the Cracked Kettle in Amsterdam. Its a purplish blue lambic with a very pretty pinkish purple head - I just love the colors. There is a vinous blueberry aroma and a subtle blueberry flavor that is sour but not tart. I would drink a lot of this if I could find it. It just keeps getting better as it warms.

Bottle shared by Marcus. 50 euro in the Netherlands! Much appreciated. Pours a dark reddish blue with a rather pinkish head. Very strong aroma of sour berry. Medium body withs pritely carbonation. Flavor of blueberry skins, and a decent refreshing sour. A clean, refreshing sour. It gets better, and more blueberry with time. Something quite unusual.

Review #1000.  I cant thank Jan enough for the opportunity to try this rarity, a 375mL bottle, 2007 vintage.

The cork came out with an impressive pop.  Pours a gorgeous hazy purplish red with a fizzy lavender head that recedes fairly quickly but does hang around as a cap for the duration.  Lacing is spotty.

The aroma is very interesting and the blueberries were evident right as I popped the cork and they seemed fairly sweet and sugary.  However, once in the glass the aroma become much more pungent and trademark Cantillon.  Its got the strong tart blueberries, a strong vinegar acidity and a healthy dose of funk.  A strong, complex and overall stunning nose.

The taste is more of the same with a strong vinegar presence up front with the blueberries coming in on the tart side of things.  There is a faint sweetness in there, but not nearly as sweet as that initial blueberry smell in the nose.  The finish is dry with lots of funk and lots of tart fruit.

The mouthfeel is spritzy with lots of carbonation and very dry and funky on the palate.

Well, Ive certainly been looking forward to this one and it didnt disappoint.  Its got lots of funk and vinegar but its much more balanced (for me) than some of the other Cantillons Ive had.  Wonderfully balanced and deserving of the praise.

Bottle; thanks to Jon via KimJohansen.  Poured a deep red with a pink head.  Aroma of blueberry, yeast and tart sourness.  Flavor was the same with a blueberry that emerged with time; some leatheriness like Jon.  A nice beer with some excellent components.

Bottle, thanks to KimJohansen.  Deep red pour with a pink head.  Seedy blueberry aroma, pretty tart overall.  Same flavor, only slight blueberry is recognizable, a little leathery funk flavor and tart overall.  Good mouthfeel.

Bottle of the 07 at BCTC.  Pours a cloudy and murky purple hued brown.  Big, but still subtle and real, blueberry aromas with some soft fuzzy funky tones to it.  Flavor is all blueberries, and blueberry skins, with a light tannin.  Slowly developing Cantillon vinegar notes and a long tangy finish.  This was delicious.  Big thanks to whomever it was that shared these (Im sure I met you, but names escape me at the moment) and to Trevor for clandestinely gathering me up and sneaking me off to the volunteer tent to try this.  Amazing.

Batch 1: 2005 and Batch 2/3: 2007 bottles tried side by side at BCTC 09 courtesy of Miver.  Thanks so, so, much for sharing these gems, Joe!   Like the others have said, and the commercial description indicates, Batch 1 is much more sour with more distinct Cantillon character while Batch 2 is more balanced and fruity and woody but still very nice.  Its all about what you like in a lambic.  I like them both, and wonder what they would have tasted like blended together.  So glad I go to try these at our epic late night blueberry lambic tasting in the volunteer tent!

Thanks to Jan & Charlotte for this treat!  Lovely deep reddish-purple colour.  Some haze.  Thin purplish head.  Bold fruity aroma shows a fair bit of wood and funk.  Good balance.  Bone dry, with a fair bit of yeastiness.  The fruit is restrained, but present, in particular lending a juicy accent to the strongly woody finish.  A bit too much yeastiness muddles the finish but overall a decent, subtle example.  2007 bottle.

05 and 07 Vintages samples courtesy of Miver. The colors vary so much from the two. 05 is lighter and not as hazy and the 07 is much red/blue color. I prefer the 07 so it has more fruit and not quite as acidic but still really nice and sour. Less vinegar and lemon than the 05. Both awesome to finally try.

small sample from rudolf at BCTC 2009 couurtesy of ???. Pours a redish pink pour. Earthy musty aroma. Taste was that earthy musty tart cantillon funk. Blueberry flavor seemed slight to be but nevertheless a outstanding beer

2007 Bottle, THANK YOU JAN & CHARLOTTE! Bright deep opaque magenta with fizzy head that does not last. Pure blueberry wafting from the bottle when the cork is popped but in the glass becomes less fruity and more about the Cantillon house character. Has a complex aroma of sour funk and blueberry jam spread on top of a nice slab of wood. Other organic smells also creep in, pineapple rind. Then tart, earthy, and phenolic aromas. The palate is fizzy and prickly. Wow, the beer is lip-puckeringly tart at first and was not noticing the blueberry either. As my palate attenuates it becomes very fruity as well as sour and the beer finishes dry and earthy. As it warms it becomes much more complex and much better as the flavors emerge. More and more drinkable too as the fruits and grains come out to add some sweetness. Lends itself to sipping and contemplation. Excellent.

Bottle. Batch 3. Pours a reddish color with a small slightly pinkish of-white head. Has a fruity tart blueberry aroma. Fruity tart berry and blueberry flavor with some hints of citrus. Has a fruity tart berry finish wit some hints of citrus and blueberry in the aftertaste.
UPDATED: JUL 1, 2010 2010 Bottle @ Ölbutikken. Ruby red with a pink head. berry aroma, blueberry, blueberry, blueberry, sour, stable horseblanket sweet citrus earthly herbs.

Thanks a bunch to FogDog and JDub for hooking me up with a taste.  This beer rocks.  Pours the color of a berry medley stuck in a blender.  Kind of a purple, blue and red color.  Nice.  Aroma is strong sour funk and strong berries.  Full of flavor and aroma with a tart berry flavor.  Delicious.

2009 bottle, thanks to KimJohansen for trading me one of these from Denmark. Wish I knew this thing was going to explode all over my kitchen counter, losing the first half-glass. Appearance is deep ruby red, cloudy, with a fine pink bubbly head. Some dark sediment settles to the bottom. I got excited, waiting for a wonderful plethora of fruity blueberry and serious barnyard funk, yet was let down at first quaff. Just a bit less complex and robust than I thought. Nose starts with funky cheese, light horseblanket / must, and biscuit. Wheres the blueberry? Flavor finally delivers blueberry, some cherry and a light citric character. Very balanced with smooth transitions, but overall seems to lack depth. Palate is smooth, finishing mildly tart with spritzy carbonation. Overall, a great beer that is balanced and highly drinkable, but I was expecting much more from both the blueberry and the funk. Not much of a desire to go after it again.

2009 vinage shared by Justin at the 6/27 Del Mar Doom.  Hmmmm, well, to start ... this thing blew up after opening.  Gusher x 10.   A gorgeous looking beer (I see this word a lot in its reviews, but its the most fitting) ... but the flavor is not nearly what I was expecting.  I couldnt pick out too much blueberry (very faint), nor much funk to speak of.  This actually fairly easy to drink w/ a quickly fading sour finish.  Wasnt stomach churning by any means.  Are the ratings rarity driven?  Is the 09 batch not up to par?  Granted, by rating will just about match the avg, but I guess I was expecting more?  Officially a let down and not worth the hassle of obtaining.  Thanks bro!

Bottle of batch 4.  Absolutely gorgeous, deep purple beer with a thick sticky deep pink head.  The aroma is just lovely.  Soft funky acidity.  Lactic with a prominent bretty funk.  Less of the Cantillon house character than I would have imagined.  Very fruity with a mix of blueberries and blackberries coming to the front.  The palate is very soft with a light chewy acidic funkiness.  Lightly earthy and spicy.  The palate is soft and silky with a lingering fruitiness.

Bottle Vintage 2009. Hazy very deep red colour with a pink head. Aroma: sour & tart with blueberries and cheese in the background. Flavor: sour & acidic (but not very sour for a Cantillon beer), lemon, blueberry soup, light funk, light wood.  Dry finish. Very refreshing. I could drink a lot of this.

From Ølbutikken, Copenhagen, DK.
Bottled, 300609.
Red with pink head. Aroma of berries and viengar. Flavor is blueberries, sourness and hints of spices.

Nose smells like a blueberry compote with a bright vinegary tartness.  
Poured a deep blood red, almost a purple hue to it, with a pink head. 
Taste is bright and clean, at cellar temp there is a lot of blueberry and tartness, but not sour. as it warms up it has hints of hay and becomes much more sour.

Fogdog is the man for opening this at the BB Bolita Release.  Pours a hazy red with a pink head.  Nose is lots of berry, yeast, cobweb, vinegar, moisture, and funk/ cobweb.  Flavor is vinegar, sour berries, tart fruit, funk, cobweb, and dryness.  Flavor levels out, and becomes enjoyable.  Medium-bodied and enjoyable.

750ml 2009 bottle generously popped by hophead84, thanks Shane!!  Pours a medium plum purple with a 1 finger thick pink head.  We heard this one was a gusher so we opened it very carefully and had no problems.  Nose of lush blueberries, Raspberries and a perfect balance between tart fruit and crisp acidity.  Flavor was nice blue/ raspberry with some Brett funk on the finish.  Very lively carbonation on the palate.  I am seriously gonna plan a Euro vacation around the next release of this bottle, Fing spectacular!

Bottle shared by fogdog at the BA Bolita release party. What a gorgeous beer. Brilliant cloudy red with a foamy thick purplish-pink head. Nose is crazy berry, with yeasty acidic notes of sourness. Light in body with huge berry notes up front before the tart sourness starts to hit you. Sour but not puckeringly so. Amazingly balanced. One of Cantillons best fruit beers. I was really glad to get to try this rare brew, thanks Kevin!

(Bottle, 2009, purchased at Ölbutikken, Copenhagen) Deep red colour with frothy, pink head. Tart, acidic, fruity nose with earthy notes of stable and barnyard, tart hints of berries (not obviously blueberries). Tart, fruity taste with sour berries (blueberries, cowberries, cranberries) and an earthy, funky sourness. Fruit never takes over, it just contributes to the balance (as usual with Cantillon). Medium body, dry and tart with that lovely refreshing Cantillon acidity that makes it so drinkable in all its extremity. Lovely beer!

[Bottle] shared by tytoanderso. Thanks a ton for sharing this one! Gushing bottle pours a beautiful deep blueish purple with a large, very creamy pink head. Nose is super funky with lots of brett, not a ton of berry, and hints of definite tartness. Flavor is initially fairly sour and tart, lots of acidity, some fruit that isnt necessarily easily identifiable as blueberry, some mineral character, and hardly any sweetness. Really fantastically creamy mouthfeel, but it dries out beautifully on the end leaving a woody and fruity finish. Awesome, awesome beer, and well worth the wait!

Pours a berry red color with a pink head. Nose is berries, lactic acid, tart unripe fruits. Flavor was loads of blueberry and sharp acidic tartness. Very nice. I need more than just a taste of this one.

UPDATED: FEB 7, 2010 Poured at CCB thanks fogdog!!!  Nice reddish/pink color.  White head.  Aroma is fruity, sour, vinegar, wet wood and funky earth tones.  Flavor is sour and fruity.  Tons of earthy notes, some bursts of tart fruits, vinegar and lively carbonation. Glad I got to try this one for sure.

750ml. 2009. Cold out of the fridge and this one is a gusher! Watch out! 
The first thing I notice about this beer is the absolutely striking appearance. Pours an absolutely gorgeous ruby pink with an amazingly frothy bright pink head. Aroma yields loads of Cantillon funk. Earthy minerals and gravel seem to override any essence of fruit. A big sniff yields just the smallest hint of tart, dried blueberry skin. Tart and acidic for sure. Earthy, funky, dirty and leathery despite all of the fruit. Cobwebby and slightly musty basement. Flavor actually shows the fruit more than the nose. A  most excellent melange of fruit, barrel and sour yeast. Not nearly as bracing in its sourness as Fou Foune or the Lou Pepes. Shows quite a bit of balance. Earthy, leafy and funky yet retains some of the blueberry skin tannins. Wonderful in its simplicity. Lush and amazingly creamy texture. Fully alive with flavor leading to a very pleasant acidity and a lightly tannic finish. Wow! Thanks a ton Nilkas! Beautiful beer all the way around.

Bottle at Cigar City BA Bolita release, courtesy fogdog. Pours a reddish dark pink, with frothy white head and tons of lacing. Nose is very tart, dry, some dark fruit as well. Flavor has a nice acidity, blueberries, cherries, some other berries, lots of fruit, dried out nicely. Pretty good. Medium-bodied, balanced, refreshing.

Huge Thanks to Fogdog and jdub for bringing this one out for the Cigar City BA Bolita release party.

A: Pours a nice deep berry red with a fizzy head with a pink tinge. Little retention and no lace.

S: Nice funky sour aroma. The berries are there but they are of the sour sort. 

T: Nice and acidic up front. The berries come out in the middle. They are in fact sour like early season strawberries with a blast of under ripe blueberries. Hints of citrus peek through along with the funky tartness found in all Cantillions.

M: Rather light to be honest, zippy carbonation.

D: Very good for the style. I usually dont find Cantillion to be real drinkable this one is.

Bottle 2009 generously shared by JoeMcPhee: Rich deep murky ruby with a deep red head- nice looking! Insane funk in the aroma- lots of cheese character (gouda rind) and cobweb. The blueberry is not sweet, rather tannic and reminiscent of the skins. Not as citric as I expected. Very light and fluffy feel. Minerally upfront- quite fruity in the flavor. Way less tartness/sourness than I expected. Soft blueberry skins and mild lactic character are evident in the fluffy body. Light, fluffy, fruity and gentle. Not as wild nor sour as I expected it. Still its a great Lambic, but I want to try the older vintages now, which according to past ratings had less fruit presence and more lactic wildness.

Bottle from MaltOMeal at the Houston sour tasting.  Thanks, man!  Pours a deep cranberry with a fizzy body.  Aroma is cranberry soda with a touch of strawberry.  Flavor is raw lemon hay.  Tingly mouthfeel.  Tastes nothing like it smells.
user_location: Ugly, Hot, and Humid Spring, Texas, USA

text: Colore rosa porpora come il succo di ciliegie non filtrato,schiuma rosea non spessa ma frizzante.Aroma di frutti di bosco, mirtilli maturi con sentori di ciliegia e mora. Il sapore è perfetto,ciliegie,limone che da acidità ricca di frutta. Perfettamente secco.Eccellente

2009 version. Bought for svogertur but just shared with evil stepdad. Deep red ruby color with a huge pink head. Lots of tiny tiny sediments. Cantillon yeast aroma, no doubt, with tart berries. Flavor is sour and tart with the usual dusty earth and lots of bitter berries. Great and very drinkable!

Botella, courtesy of Pinball. 2009 version. Lovely typical Cantillon sourness in the aroma with berries.  Cloudy deep dak red/pink colour. Very good mouthfeel. Flavour: sour, very pleasantly sour, good fruitiness, berries and a dry sour fruity finish. Yum!

batch4 2009 vintage. small bottle shared with faroeviking.
beware! the 2009 version is eager to leave the bottle, open in a sink and have glasses ready.
pours deep red with a small pink head. looks fantastic but i always subtract points if the beer explodes out of the bottle.
aroma is sour, berries, very sour slight leather. aroma is very good, balanced between extremely sour and berries.
flavor is sour, very well blended, some blueberries, very refreshing.
a great cantillon, very drinkable.

UPDATED: JUN 4, 2009 Bottled sample, thanks to Todeon and andersand. Pours a beutiful purple/red color with white head. Aroma is fruity with notes of bluberries and funk. Flavour is very fruity and of course tart with berries. Quite dry, but with some sweeter notes from the berries, some earthy and grassy notes even, and a balanced funkyness. Very good stuff indeed. More balanced than their standard kriek for example - though its still sour, its not as extreme and just utterly tasty.

Batch 3 pours hazy ruby color with a thin off white head.  Looks almost pink.  Aroma is perfect.  Blueberry, some funk, tart acidic character, and a touch more blueberry.  I could just smell this all night.  Medium light mouthfeel with a lot of carbonation.  Flavor had blueberry, tart acid, funk, and had a nice balance between the fruit and the funk.  The blueberry flavor was a little subdued on the taste.  Otherwise this has got to be one of my favorites.  Thanks Brad for sharing this!

Sampled at Houston RB tasting. Thanks to Maltomeal. Hazy, light purple color. Small white head. Nose is fruity, tart, tangy. Very effervescent, lemony, tart, tangy. I didnt get much blueberry on this one but over a very tasty and well done beer.
user_location: Seattle still not near Beersel., Washington, USA

text: March Houston Tasting. Thanks to MaltOMeal. Pours pink with bubbly head. Nose of tart blueberries and a touch of cherries. Flavor is sour blueberries, but it is not overwhelming like many Lambics can be. Dry, but not too dry. Easy to drink and very enjoyable.

750ml bottle thanks to Papsoe.  Shared at the March Houston Tasting.  Pours a colorful burgundy with a pink, bubbly head.  Fantastic nose of blueberries.  Taste is of sour blueberries.  Very tasty!  Mouthfeel is medium with some sourness, but not overly so.  This was very drinkable.

370ml bottle. 2007 Vintage.
Looks like carbonated blueberry juice.
Tastes of sour blueberries and candy.

UPDATED: NOV 15, 2009 Bottle. Look: Looks like watery blueberry soup. Smell: The sour sparkling wine/vineager thing dominates the aroma. But there is also lots of berries in the background. Taste: Sour beer with a natural blueberry taste. Perfect tartness in the aftertaste. Overall: Really good fruit lambic. Not too sour, not too sweet. In Sweden a beer geek would call this a "lagom sur disktrasa".

Ive had the pleasure of tasting several bottles ( 75cl & 37.5cl) of this fine fruit Lambik; vintage 2007 Batch 1 & 2.  Pours a light to medium burgundy with slight white head!
